JOHN HARRISON and
GEORGE LEWIS were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of Jan., 2 tame rabbits, price 6s.; the property of
James Tillier.

JAMES TILLIER . On the 5th of Jan. I had two rabbits safe in the shed—I missed them the same evening—I went after the prisoners towards Houns
low, and met a policeman—I have seen the two rabbits again—I saw the prisoners going from my mother's cottage on the 5th.
CHARLES BAKER . I bought these two rabbits from the prisoners, between four and five o'clock, on the 5th of Jan.—one was alive and one dead, but warm.

Harrison's Defence. I met a man close by a row of trees; he asked if I knew any body likely to buy two rabbits; he wanted 4s. I said I bad no money, I would give him a cod-fish and nine fresh herrings, and he took them.
Lewis's Defence. I was along with him for a walk, and when he bought these, I carried them for him.

CHARLES BAKER
re-examined. They said they changed a cod-fish and seven fresh herrings for them—I gave 2s. and a pint of beer for them—they had a rabbit each.
(The prisoners received a good character.)

HARRISON—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

743.
HENRY PERCY,
ALFRED COLLINS , and
FRANCIS WHIT
TLE were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 1 till, value 1s.; 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 4 groats, 5 pence, 26 halfpence, and 9 farthings; the property of
James Piggott.

JAMES PIGGOTT . I am a baker, and live in High-street, Notting-hill. On the 21st of Jan., about five o'clock in the evening, I was sitting with my wife, in the parlour at the back of the shop—I saw a boy running out of the shop—I ran tothe door, and saw the three prisoners taking the money out of my till, which was on the ground—I cannot say how much there was in the till—there was a shilling—I ran after the prisoners and overtook them—I first caught two, and then the other—I am quite sure they are the boys.

MARY ANN PIGGOTT . There were 12s. in the till, in shillings, sixpence, and pence—I followed my husband, and saw the three prisoners—they had the till in their hands—Whittle held it, and they all had their hands in it.
Collins. The lady said she had taken the money from the till three minutes before. Witness. No, I said I had taken some money from the till.
WILLIAM PALMER . I searched the prisoners, and found some silver and copper on Collins.
ROBERT DUNNETT ( police-constable F 198.) I was on duty, and was called to take the prisoners—I found no money on them.
Callins's Defence. I was full fifty yards off; the gentleman beckoned, and I came to him. The money I had belonged to my father.

PERCY*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

COLLINS*—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

WHITTLE*—
GUILTY . Aged 12.

744.
JAMES LICKFOLD was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan. 3/4 lb. weight of Indian rubber, value 2s., the goods of
John Faulkner.

SARAH LEFACE . I live with my uncle, John Faulkner, a stationer, in Queen-street, Tower-hill. About half-past nine o'clock, on the 23rd of Jan., I was in the kitchen, and heard a click of a lock, and saw the prisoner run
ning out from behind the counter—I ran, and caught him three doors off—he dropped this piece of Indian rubber, which is my uncle's.
WILLIAM LOOKER . I saw the prisoner drop the Indian rubber.

GUILTY . * Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

745.
WILLIAM CONNOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Spikins, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES SPIKINS . I live at the Sceptre Coffee-house, Lincoln's Inn-fields. About nine o'clock, on the 24th of Jan., I was passing down Broad-street, Bloomsbury—I felt something at my pocket—I turned, and saw the prisoner, with my handkerchief in his hand—I called "Stop thief," ran after him, and overtook him at the corner of Great St. Andrew-street—he threw the hand
kerchief into a cart just before the officer took him—I saw it safe about two minutes before.
JOHN GEARY (police-constable F 79.) I saw the prisoner running, And saw him throw this handkerchief into a cart.
GEORGE ANDREWS (police-constable G 66.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

746.
JOHN HEDDINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan., 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Holt, from his person.

EDWARD HOLT . I live in Great Bland-street, Dover-road; on the 23rd of Jan. I was passing from Duke-street to Lincoln's Inn-fields—I heard a noise, looked back, and found a gentleman with the prisoner in his arms—I went on, and found my handkerchief was gone—this is it.

JAMES DILLON . I was going through Lincoln's Inn-fields with Holt—I heard a cry, and saw a gentleman holding the prisoner—I went on, then I looked round again, and saw the officer had got the prisoner—I saw the handkerchief taken from his trowsers' pocket.
THOMAS HALL (police-constable G 144.) I found this handkerohief in the prisoner's trowsers' pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I was passing down Duke-street; I saw the prosecu
tor drop his handkerchief from his pocket; I took it up, and was following him, when I was seized by two gentlemen, who said they saw me take it.

GUILTY . † Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
747.
WILLIAM BEER was indicted
for feloniously receiving, of an evil-disposed person, on the 14th of Jan., 30lbs. weight of lead, value 5s., the goods of
Francis Bursell.

FRANCIS BURSELL . I am a plumber and painter, in Cleveland-street, Fitz
roy-square. On Saturday, the 24th of Jan., I lost some lead from the roof of the workshop and back parlour—on the following Wednesday, in consequence of information, I went to the prisoner's house, in Warren-street, St. Paneras, in the neighbourhood where I reside—I saw the prisoner—I asked him if he had bought any lead—he said he had—I asked if he could give it to me—he said he could not, as it was melted down and sold—he said he had bought it of George Henry Wallington, whom I took with me.

Cross-examined by Mr. BALLANTINE. Q. You received some communica
tion from Wallington? A. Yes—he told me he had stolen it—I told him, if he would tell the truth with respect to it, I would deal mildly with him—I had lost a tremendous lot of things—the prisoner told me he had bought some lead of that boy, and it was melted and gone—he concealed nothing from me—he behaved with the greatest possible openness—I did not give him into custody—he walked with me to the police-office, he was admitted to bail, and surrendered—I have had a good many communications with Wallington since, and I think he has told a good many untruths.
NOT GUILTY .

(There were two other indictments against the prisoner, on which no evi
dence was offered.)

748.
MUNSON SAYERS was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 16th of Jan., 3 soldering-irons, value 3s. 6d.; and 1 iron ladle, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Francis Bursill.

FRANCIS BURSILL . I lost some soldering-irons on the 16tn of Jan.—I went to the prisoner's, and found them there—his wife pointed them out—she said, "If they are yours, take them, my husband is not at home, but when he
comes in I will send him to the Magistrate"—the prisoner said that the boy Wallington went to his house, and said he had had no breakfast, and he let him have a few halfpence on the irons.
NOT GUILTY .

749.
JOSEPH SWAINE and
WILLIAM SADD were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 19th of Jan., 1 horse-collar, value 5s.; 1 bridle, 8s.; 1 pair of harness, 1s.; 1 pair of traces, 2s.; 1 crupper, 1s.; and 1 curry-comb, 1s.; the goods of
Philemon Harvey.

FRANCIS RUWALD . I am in the service of Mr. Philemon Harvey, a fancy trimming maker, Osborn-place, Whitechapel. This harness is his—I saw them safe in his stable on Thursday morning, the 19th of Jan.—I saw them again on the Saturday following.

GEORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant H 8.) On Thursday night, the 19th of Jan., I saw both the prisoners together at the door of No. 23, St. John-street—I think they saw me—they both rushed into the house, and up stairs—the street-door was pushed to—I ran to the door, and heard more than one person running up stairs—I got a light, went up, and found both the prisoners stand
ing together on the top of the second stairs, and behind them was a black bag containing this harness—I said, "Halloo, who does this belong to?"—Swaine said, "It belongs to a person I know"—I said, "Who is he, and where does he live?"—he said, "I tell you it belongs to a person I know, what do you want more?"—I took them and the bag.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. The bag was lying on the floor? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

750.
JOHN YOUNG was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of Jan., 1 a watch, value 10l.; I watch-key, 3d.; and I watch-ribbon, 3d.; the goods of
Frederick Henry Ridley, in his dwelling-house: and
WILLIAM SCOTT
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.: and that Scott had been before convicted of felony.

LOUISA HOWES . I am servant to Mr. Frederick Henry Ridley, of Broom
field-row, Maida-hill, Paddington. I saw Young about a quarter past twelve o'clock on the morning of the 18th of Jan., in my master's scullery—I did not know him before—he was not dressed as a butcher, but he had a page's jacket on, and a piece of beef in a butcher's tray, which had not been ordered—he left the beef in the scullery—I said, "This is not for here"—he said, "It is"—I asked where he brought it from, and he mentioned a name which I cannot recollect—I left him in the scullery, and went to the dining-room to ask my mistress about it—I came back in about two minutes, and found him where I had left him—I again said, "I don't think it is right"—he said it was, and went out—I followed him, and locked the door—I returned to the kitchen in about three minutes, and missed my mistress's gold watch off the shelf—it had a key attached to it by a ribbon—I know it was safe about ten minutes before—it was gold, and was worth more than 10l.—I am quite sure it was there—I made inquiries, and my mistress had not ordered the beef—I am quite sure Young is the lad—the watch has not been found.

Young. I did not go out till a quarter to twelve o'clock, and was back by a quarter past; it was not me; you said it was ten minutes after, I was gone you missed it. Witness. No, I said in three minutes after I looked to see what time it was, and the watch was gone—there was no one there but you and I.
GEORGE IBBS . I am going on for twelve years old, and live in Union-street,

Lission-grove—I know both the prisoners well—Scott lives down Clarement
place—I have seen him and Young together nearly every morning—I re
member Wednesday, the 18th of Jan.—I was working with my father in Mr. Ridley's garden—I saw Young come there—he had a tray with a bit of beef in it—I am sure it was him—he went down into the kitchen with the beef—he was in the house about two minutes—when he got out of the gar
den-gate be ran to Scott, who was about ten yards from the gate, and I saw him take something out of his pocket and give it into Scott's hand—Scott took the article, and I saw there was a ribbon, and a key hanging to the bot
tom of the ribbon—Scott had it at that time in his hand, and he put it into his pocket—Young then ran up the hill, and Scott walked gently after him—I am quite sure the prisoners are the boys—I went to the station for a po
liceman.
Young. Q. How do you know me? A. You used to come to call Scott almost every morning—that was about a year ago.

Scott. Q. Do you say you saw the watch? A. No—I saw something—I followed Young out of the gate—when he gave it into your hand you put it into your pocket, and he ran, and you walked after him—you were then about thirty yards off—I did not say before that I was in the garden stooping down—I never was in trouble but once, and that was for throwing a stone—I do not know what Young gave you, but I saw a key and a ribbon—I did not say that you stood still for five minutes—you walked on—when I saw him give it you, I stood against the gate, and when the servant came out I told her—I had a good mind to run and tell her directly.

SAMUEL HAMPTON (police-sergeant D 24.) I received information from lbbs, about one o'clock, on the 18th of Jan., that this watch was lost—I went and found Scott in Church-street, Portman-market—he said he knew nothing about it—I then went after Young—I found him at home, at No. 26, Little Carlisle-street—he said he knew nothing about it, and he did not know where Broomfield-row was—he was dressed in this page's jacket and this hat, and the same trowsers and boots that he now has on—he looked like a servant.

Young's Defence. I went out at a quarter to twelve o'clock, and heard of a place; I went home, and put on my other clothes, and went after it at Dr. Brook's, No. 1, Middlesex-place, New-road—he was engaged; I then went to Chelsea for an accordion, and came back; I had this dress when I was page at Dr. Bruce's, in Montague-street.
Scott's Defence. I was at home, I can assure you, at the time the boy says he saw me.

LAWARENCE ANDERSON . I produce a certificate of Scott's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present—he is the person who was then convicted by the name of Henry Thompson.
(Young received a good character.)

YOUNG—
GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury, —
Confined Six Months.

SCOTT—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against Scott.)

751.
THOMAS CALLAGHAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 1 fender, value 3s., the goods of
Henry William Hill.

HENRY WILLIAM HILL . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Penny-fields, Poplar. This fender is mine—I lost it on Tuesday week—I had it safe in my shop at half-past six o'clock that evening—I then went out, and returned
at half-past eight, and missed it—I think I have seen the prisoner in the neighbourhood.

ELIZA WILLIS . I am servant to Mr. Hill. He went out that evening—he left me and my mistress at home—about eight o'clock I went out for the supper beer—when I came back I missed a fender from the window—I will not be sure that it was safe when I went out.

HENRY WOOD (police-sergeant K 44.) On the evening of the 24th of Jan. I was on duty in Ropemaker's-fields, Limehouse—I saw the prisoner with this fender under his arm—I asked where he got it—he said he bought it at a broker's, named Burns, in the Highway, for 2s., and he was going to take it to his sister's—I said he must go with me to the shop—he walked about two hundred yards, and then made a cut at my legs with the fender—it got between his own legs—he tripped, and ran away—I fell down—he turned into a court, which was no thoroughfare, and I caught him.
Prisoner. I said I bought it of a man named Burns, I did not say a broker. Witness. He said a broker, named Burns—I knew there was no such person.
Prisoner's Defence. I do not know where Burns lives, but it is in Poplar.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Two Months.

752.
JAMES KENNY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of January, I pistol, value 4s.; and 2 handkerchiefs, 3s.; the goods of
John Painter.

JOHN PAINTER . I am a butcher, and live in Pierpoint-row, Islington. I lost a black silk handkerchief similar to this one, but I cannot swear to it—I missed it last Sunday morning week, from an apartment in a house I sleep in—I live in one house and sleep in another—I went down to the landlady, and told her—I then looked for another handkerchief, and missed that—that hand
kerchief is here now, and I can speak to it—I also lost a small pistol, similar to this one, but I cannot swear to this—I cannot tell whether I lost these things at one time—I did not miss the pistol till I heard the prisoner was appre
hended—I had seen him about the premises—the last time I saw him was on the Saturday.

THOMAS FIELD . I live in Adelaide-square, Islington. I saw the prisoner in the evening of this day fortnight—he asked me to buy this black silk hand
kerchief of him—I did not want it, but he came after me again, and I bought it—I afterwards took it to the station.
Prisoner. This lad was here for stealing a quartern loaf, and had three months in the House of Correction. Witness. Yes, I had.

JAMES COOK . I am shopman to Mr. Good burn, a pawnbroker. I pro
duce this other handkerchief, which was pawned by the prisoner—I am sure of that.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

753.
GEORGE LESTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 4 planes, value 6s.; 3 saws, 5s.; 1 augur, 1s.; 1 screw-driver, 1s.; 1 chi
sel, 1s.; and 1 square, 2s.; the goods of
John Pearce.

THOMAS PEARCE . I live with my father, John Pearce, at Shepherd's Bush; he is a carpenter, and is finishing the house where we are residing; the prisoner is a plasterer, and was employed there by my father—we had some tools, which I put into a box, on the 20th of Jan., which was put into the next room to the one we live in—there were four planes, and the other articles stated in the indictment in it—these are the tools—they are my father's.
Prisoner. I removed them from the kitchen up to that room. Witness. No, I took them up myself.

HENRY HAMPSTEAD . I conduct the business of Mr. Aldhouse, a pawn
broker,

at Hammersmith. On the 21st of Jan. this plane and this saw were pawned by the prisoner; on the 25th he pawned a screw-driver and square; on the 26th another plane; he also pawned some more tools, but I did not take them in—they were all pawned in the name of Smith—the duplicates produced by the officer are those I gave the prisoner.
JOHN PAISLEY (police-constable T 86.) I took the prisoner last Tuesday—I found on him fifteen duplicates, eight of which refer to this property.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor was taken ill on the Thursday, and the day after I packed up all his tools and took them up into an upper bed-room, and they laid there all the following week—I had no work to do that week—I sat up with him two nights, and stopped with him two days; I merely took the tools, as I wanted a shilling or two that week, not intending to rob him—I had the duplicates all carefully in my pocket, to get them out; I did not deny the fact when I was taken; I had commenced work again the day I was taken.

THOMAS PEARCE
re-examined. I have known him since last June, but have not worked with him—I never knew anything wrong of him—it is true about my father being ill, and that he sat up with him two or three nights.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Two Months.

754.
HENRY THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Jan., 1 printed book, value 1s., the goods of
Isaac Henry Hatfield.

ISAAC HENRY HATFIELD . I am a bookseller, and live in Chapel-st., Totten
ham-court-road. This is my book—I missed it from a board outside my win
dow, on Tuesday evening, the 24th of Jan.—I had seen it safe on the 22nd.

ANN RAWLINGS . I am the wife of John Edward Rawlings, a bookseller, in Tottenham-court-road. On the afternoon of the 25th of Jan. the prisoner offered me this book for sale—he said he had purchased it of a boy in the street the week before, and given him 6d. for it—I gave him in charge on suspicion.
FREDERICK CLARK (police-constable E 155.) I received the prisoner in charge, and this book.
Prisoner's Defence. A boy asked me to sell it for him.

GUILTY . * Aged 14.—
Confined Fourteen Days, and
Whipped.

755.
MARY ANN MANLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Dec., 1 1/4 yard of satin, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Gwyther.

SARAH TUCKER . I am the wife of William Tucker, of Warren-street, Tottenham-court-road. I have known the prisoner nearly two years—she had been my servant, and left me in Nov., 1841—she came to me before last Christmas, I do not know the day, and asked me if I would accept of this satin—it had been a bonnet, but was not a bonnet then—this bonnet (pro
ducing it) was made of it.

WILLMOT GWYTHER . I am the wife of Thomas Gwyther, of Tunbridge-street, New-road. The prisoner came to my house several times before Christmas—I missed about a yard and a quarter of satin from my back-kitchen—it was for making a bonnet—I left the prisoner in my front-kitchen the day I missed it—I went to market, and when I came home I missed it, but I do not know that it had been taken that day—the prisoner said it must be the washerwoman who had taken it, and I accused the woman of it—I am quite sure this bonnet is made of that satin.
ELIZA GWYTHER . I remember this satin being lost—the prisoner was at our house that day—when my mother spoke about it, she said it must have been the washerwoman.
Prisoner. She gave me the satin; it was a bonnet, which had been given to her. Witness. I am sure I never gave it to her.

SARAH TUCKER
re-examined. When she gave it me, she said a friend of hers, who was a dressmaker, gave it her—I heard her say that Mr. Gwyther's daughter gave it to her.
NOT GUILTY .

756.
MARY ANN MANLEY was again indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of July, 1 thimble, value 1s. 6d.; and 3 towels, 3s.; the goods of
William Tucker.

SARAH TUCKER . I am the wife of William Tucker. I have known the prisoner two years—she was in my service fourteen or fifteen months ago—after she left I missed three towels and a thimble—these are them—(looking at them)—when the prisoner called occasionally at my house, I told her I had lost them, and she helped me to look for the thimble, which I lost some time after she left her situation, and was in the habit of calling on me—I think it must have been between the latter end of April and the beginning of July—the prisoner came to me in June, 1841, and left in Nov.—she returned at the latter end of April, 1842, and was with me up to the 28th of June, and then left me—I suppose that was the time I lost the thimble.

JURY. Q. Have you your name on these towels? A. No, but I made them, and have been in the habit of washing and ironing them—I know this thimble perfectly—there is no mark on it, but I am familiar with it, and it fits me exactly—it is nearly new—the prisoner was occasionally at my house—she finally left about the 1st of July—I have found two more towels, which were also mine.
WILLIAM MURDOCK. I am shopman to Mr. Flemming, a pawnbroker, in Farringdon-street—I produce there towels, pawned on the 31st August—I cannot say by whom—I gave a duplicate of them.
JAMES HENRY STEWARD . I am shopman to Mr. Kirkman, a pawnbroker. I have a thimble, pawned by Allener, on the 15th of July.
JOHANNA ALLENER . The prisoner gave me this thimble to pawn for her, which I did.

Prisoner. I left it at her house, and she pawned it without my knowledge. Witness. The prisoner gave it me, and asked me to pawn it for her, and I pawned it, I think, the same day, or a day or two after.
SUSANNAH BURTON . I searched the prisoner at the station, on the 14th of Jan.—I found on her six duplicates, in a tin-box—I gave them to the officer.

EDWARD HURST (police-constable E 23.) On the 14th of Jan. I took the prisoner on suspicion of stealing a quantity of wearing apparel—I received from Burton these duplicates, two of which correspond with these articles, and with the counterparts produced by the pawnbroker.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 28th of June, Mrs. Tucker had words with me, and I left her on the 29th; I staid at Mr. Cole's till the 1st of July; I never was in her house again till October; the towels are my own, and so is the thimble.

GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

757.
MARY ANN COWARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Jan., 1 scarf, value 2s.; 1 shawl, 10s.; 1 gown, 10s.; 1 bonnet, 3s.; 1 purse, 3d.; 1 cross, 1s.; 1 neck-chain, 2s.; 2 pairs of boots, 1l.; 1 coat, 8s.; 1 watch-chain, 2l.; 2 seals, 10s.; 1 watch-key, 5s.; 1 ring, 5s.; 1 brooch, 1l.; 2 handkerchiefs, 5s.; 1 half-crown, I shilling, 2 groats, and 2 pence; the property of
Stephen William New; and that she had been before con
victed of felony.

STEPHEN WILLIAM NEW . I am a musician, and live in Upper Mary-le
bone-street—the prisoner it the daughter of my laundress—I misted a number of articles from my sitting-room, part of them on Sunday evening, the 1st of Jan., and part on the Monday—I missed a gold watch-chain, seals, key, and ring from the corner of the piano, in the sitting-room—I afterwards missed the pearl cross, the scarf, and other things stated—this is the chain, scarf, cross, purse, gown, shawl, and bonnet—they are my wife's, and were in my sitting-room.

HENRY FOWLER (police-constable E 111.) I took the prisoner on the 3rd of Jan., in Tottenham-court-road—she had this scarf, shawl, gown, and bonnet on, and this chain and cross was round her neck—I took her to the station—she said, "Let me go, and take off the things, as I have got my own things under them"—they were taken off, and she had her other things under them.
Prisoner. They belong to Mrs. Hollis.

STEPHEN WILLIAM NEW
re-examined. I kept this chain and cross in a drawer at the top of a cash-box—it was not locked—these are my wife's pro
perty, who is here—her name was Hollis before she was married.
ROBERT ADAMS (police-constable 109 E.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
758.
EMMA JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Jan., 3 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 4 shillings and sixpence, the monies of
John Williams, from his person; and that she had been before convicted of felony.
MR. CLARKSON offered no evidence, the prosecutor's name not being correct in the indictment.
NOT GUILTY .

759.
ELIZA MATENOT and
MARY ANN JOHNSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of Jan., 2 hams, value 15s., the goods of
John Taylor; and that they had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN TAYLOR . I am an oilman, and live in Jermyn-street. At half-past eight on Saturday night the prisoners came into my shop—Matenot asked for an ounce of pepper—she gave me a fourpenny-piece—I gave change—I sus
pected them—I watched, and saw a shuffling between their shawls the moment I served them—I came round the counter and missed two hams—I pursued them—they had turned up a passage, where I found them, and said, "You have got my hams; you had better give them up"—then one dropped, and then another dropped—a light was got in the house they ran into, and the two hams were found in the dark passage—I cannot say from which they fell.
THOMAS MARCHANT (police-constable C 49.) I was sent for, took the prisoners, and found the hams in the passage.
Matenot's Defence. I did not ask for the pepper; it was the other put down the fourpenny-piece.
EEWARD TANNER (police-constable E 56.) I produce a certificate of
Matenot's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office (read)—Matenot is the person that was tried.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) I produce a certi
ficate of Johnson's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office (read)—she is the person who was tried.

MATENOT—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

760.
WILLIAM WESTON was indicted
for embezzling and stealing 2s. 6d., the monies of
Joshua Chipchase, his master.

JOSHUA CHIPCHASE . I am a shoemaker, and live in High-street, Shadwell. The prisoner was in my employ about sixteen months—in consequence of something in the week previous to the 9th of Jan. I agreed with Mr. Barrett to mark a half-crown—about ten o'clock on the 9th of Jan. I went down into my shop and asked the prisoner to account for what money he had taken—he said 5s. 6d. for a pair of boots, and 2s. 6d. for a pair of shoes, which had just gone out—I said, "Has there been nothing else sold?"—he said "No"—I said, "You sold a pair of slippers for half-a-crown at nine o'clock"—he said, "Yes, but you had the money for them." I had been called down at ten minutes past nine, and there was a customer in the shop, who bought a pair of slippers for half-a-crown—I had got that half-crown—I said, "Yes, but you sold a pair exactly at nine"—he denied it—if he had sold another pair at nine, and bad received half-a-crown for them, he was half-a-crown short in the money he had accounted to me for—I told him that when I came down at five minutes past nine I lifted up the lid of the desk, and in a back place, where money never was kept, I saw the edge of a half-crown—he said, "I suppose you put it there"—I said, "No, but I will tell you how it came there"—I told him for a long time I had suspected he was robbing me, and for the last few weeks I was quite sure of it—he denied it—I said, "Have you a half-crown about you?"—he said, "Yes"—he then threw down two half-crowns and two shillings on the counter—I told him that the half-crown with which the slippers were purchased was marked, and on taking up one it was marked—I sent for Mr. Barrett, and in the prisoner's presence asked him if he knew that half-crown—he said yes, it was the one marked.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had the prisoner lived with you before?—A. Yes, once; he left to get married—I gave him a very bad character, but the clergyman believed him rather than me—there was 100l. due to him on his marriage, if he could get a good character; and he applied to me, but I gave him a bad character—I took him again, because I hoped he was better—I agreed with him that he was to stay a year, if he conducted him
self to my entire satisfaction, so that I could not discharge him within the year—the errand-boy was present when I had this conversation about the slippers—I never allowed the prisoner to give change out of his own pocket—there were always persons in the house to do so, my wife or my daughters—I never told him not to give change in so many words, but it was not his habit—this is a book in which he ought to enter these things—he has nothing to do with the daily expenses book.

Prisoner. The man Collins made a pair of bespoke shoes in the name of Wells—he brought them to me while I had a customer in the shop, and wanted to be paid—I said I had nothing less than a half-crown—I put my hand in my pocket and gave him a shilling, and asked if that would do.
Witness. I have no recollection of that—if he had, it was his business to have told me, and he never said a word about it.

MR. DOANE. Q. Did the prisoner ever ask for the daily expense book before the Magistrate? A. No—whether he gave change or not, there is still balf-a-crown short in what he accounted for, supposing there had been a pair sold at nine o'clock.
JAMES BARRETT . I am a grocer, and live in High-street, Shadwell. On the 8th of Jan. I marked a half-crown, and gave it to my brother Daniel—this is it.
Cross-examined. Q. What mark did you put upon it? A. Two nicks above the crown, on the reverse of the coin.
DANIEL BARRETT . I received a half-crown from my brother—I saw the mark on it, and gave it to my sister.
ANN BARRETT . I received the half-crown from my brother, and gave it to Elizabeth Murray, who was in our service, and gave her directions what to do with it.

ELIZABETH MURRAY . I was in the service of Miss Barrett. I received from her this half-crown—I took it to Mr. Chipchase's shop, to buy a pair of slippers, at nine o'clock precisely—Shadwell clock was striking—I bought a pair of slippers—they came to half-a-crown—I gave the prisoner the half-crown that was given to me by my mistress.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there any other customers in the shop? A. No.
WILLIAM KEELEY (police-constable K 175.) I received this half-crown from the prosecutor.

JOSEPH CHIPCHASE
re-examined. This is the half-crown I found on the prisoner—he lent me 3s. 6d. before breakfast that morning, but it was paid him again.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined One Year.

761.
HENRY SCREW was indicted
for embezzlement.
ELIZA MORRISH . I am single, and deal with Mr. Gardner. On the 27th of Dec. I paid the prisoner 6s. 10d. for some meat I had of his master.

BENJAMIN GARDNER . I have not received this 6s. 10d.—it was the pri
soner's business to have given it me the same evening, but he absconded.
Prisoner. He is indebted to me more than this. Witness. I am not—he is in my debt 17s. for money he drew from me and my wife.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Four Months.

762.
THOMAS WOOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Jan., 2lbs. weight of mutton, value 1s.; and 3/4lb. weight of pork, 6d.; the goods of
Benjamin Gardner.

BENJAMIN GARDNER . I am a butcher, and live at Ealing. The prisoner was employed for me—on the 7th of Jan. he said he was ill—after I had come from Bow-street about the last case, the prisoner said, "Master, honesty is the best policy, I will look out"—I then missed a loin of mutton, and sent my son round—the prisoner came in, and said he was very bad in his inside—there were eleven chops on the stall—he said he would go away for a minute or two—I missed the chops—I ran, and saw him running up a court into a coffee-shop—I saw a man with some chops—he was going to put them into a pan—I said, "Who gave you these?"—he said, "Your man"—I went back and took the prisoner—I did not find any more chops, or the loin of mutton.
Prisoner. I never saw them. Witness. They were there not a minute before you left.
THOMAS FISHER . I keep a coffee-shop in Charles-street. On this evening

the prisoner brought in two chops, one mutton and one pork, and the prose
cutor came in immediately.
JONATHAN BUSH (police-constable F 40.) I took the prisoner—he said he had only taken two chops for his tea, he thought there was no harm in that.
Prisoner's Defence. There was some stinking meat brought out, and I could not eat it.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

763.
JOSEPH ALLEN and
THOMAS FEALEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of Jan., 6 tame fowls, price 12s., the property of
Richard Eaton.

RICHARD EATON . I live in St. Luke's—I have a stable in Cowper-street, I saw my fowls safe at four o'clock, on the 19th of Jan.—I was called by the policeman about one in the night of the 20th—my fowls were then gone—I have examined these—they are mine—Fealey lived with me about seven weeks—I know Allen, but he had not lived with me.

HENDRY SMITH (police-constable G 44.) I stopped Allen in Old-street, about half-past ten o'clock at night, on the 19th—Fealey was with him—I took these fowls from Allen—he said he brought them from the Vinegar-ground—they were dead, but quite warm—he said he sold them, because they had got the croop.
(Fealey received a good character.)

ALLEN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

FEALEY—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

764.
JOHN COOK was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Jan., 2lbs. weight of tobacco, value 1s. 6d.; and 3 cigar-cases, 6d.; the goods of
Philip Joseph Marie John Baptiste Pavia; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

PHILIP JOSEPH MARIE JOHN BAPTISTE PAVIA . I am a tobacconist, and live in High-Holborn. I had some cigar-cases and cigars safe about seven o'clock, on the 19th of Jan.—I missed them about half-past—these are them.
THOMAS FISH (police-constable E 43.) I stopped the prisoner with these things on the 19th of Jan., about nine o'clock in the evening.

Prisoner. A person met me, and said, "If you will carry this I will give you something." Witness. He said he had them given to him, but did not say by whom; he said he was going to take them to Baldwin's-gardens; I went there, and found it was an empty house.

JOHN ABREY (police-constable G 117.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

765.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Jan., I cart, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
John Cooper.

JOHN COOPER . I am a builder, and live in Newland-street, Pimlico. On the 13th of Jan. the prisoner came and asked me to let him have my cart to sell it—I said, "No, you shall not take the cart without you bring the money first"—he had had it before for sale—he did not bring me any money for it—I did not permit him in any way to take it—he came up to me on the 21st, and said, "I am very sorry, master, I have sold your cart, and lost the money"—I said, "As soon as I can see a policeman I shall give you in charge."

FREDERICK COOPER . The prisoner came and asked if I would let him have the cart—I said, "Not without my father's permission"—he went away, then came back, and said my father had given him leave, and I let him have it.

Prisoner. His father was at the Wellington; I went there, and he gave me leave to do the best I could, and told me not to bring it home if it was late, but to take it to Mr. Digby's—the next morning I went to his build
ings in the Vauxhall-road, and did not see him; in coming back, I saw him, and spoke to him; he sent my brother to know whether I had told the cart; I told him when I met him that he should not lose a farthing; I would pay 10s. a week; I do not live a stone's throw from him.
JOHN COOPER . It was above ten days before I cound find where he lived—I lost the cart on the 13th, and he did not come to me till the 21st.
STEPHEN SMITH . I am the prisoner's brother. The prosecutor sent down to me, to know if my brother had sold the cart, as he had bad it long enough to sell—I said I did not know.

GEORGE CURRY . About six weeks ago I met the prisoner in George-street—he said he was going to sell the cart and horse—he sold the horse, but could not sell the cart—he brought it back, and the prosecutor's son let him in at the gate.
NOT GUILTY .

756.
GEORGE TAYLOR,
DAVID KING , and
WILLIAM WATSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of Jan., 350lbs. weight of lead, value 2l. 10s.; 850lbs. weight of iron, 2l.; and 1 sink, 10s.; the goods of
Sir Ro
bert Fitz Wygram, Bart., and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.—Four other COUNTS, stating it to belong to William Reid and others, and William Blencowe.

WILLIAM THORNTON . I am a painter, and live in Hatton-wull. Enrly in the morning of Thursday, the 20th of July, I saw King come out of No. 27, with part of a cast-iron furnace—there was a van at the door, and King gave it to the van-man—Taylor then brought out some iron bars of the furnace, and gave them to the van-man—Taylor then came out, accompanied by Watson, with a sack containing the lead of a water-closet—he gave that to the van
man—Watson and King brought out the lead lining of a cistern—I went up to Mr. Knot, at Mr. Reed's, the brewhouse—I then found Fink, the police
man—he came to the house.

JOHN FINK (police-constable G 47.) Thornton made a communication to me—I went to No. 27, Hatton-wall—I found a van at the door—I saw Tay
lor bring out a sack—I got into the van, and found it contained lead—it appeared to be the bottom of a water-cistern—I found three other sacks in the van, containing pipes, and part of a water-closet—I fitted these things to what remained on the premises, and they corresponded exactly—I went to the house—Taylor shut the door in my face—I got another officer, and got into the house—I there found Taylor—he said I had no right to interfere with people moving their own property in open day-light—I saw Watson in the shop, and King in the parlour—I asked Watson what he was doing—he said he merely came in to be shaved—King said he was a lodger, and they had nothing to do with the moving, they were only employed by the landlord to move the things—there was not the slightest appearance of shaving—some part of the shutters were down, and some up—I sent for Mr. Knott, the managing clerk of the brewery—King then said he wanted some
thing to drink, and ordered coffee of the woman in the parlour, and they all partook of it—I went over the premises—in the back-house the whole of the roof was off, and the furnace and iron-work was gone—the lead I found fitted it—Mr. Knott came, and gave the prisoners in charge—as we were going

along, Watson said he assisted in moving the things, and was to hare some
thing to eat and drink for his trouble—there was 350Ibs. of lead in the van, a stone sink, and 850lbs. of iron.

JOHN KNOTT . I am managing clerk to William Reid and others, brewers—No. 27, Hatton-wall, is their freehold property. On the 13th of Jan. the policeman sent for me about half-past nine o'clock—I went, and found them in the state described, and the van loaded—the damage is to the amount of 60l.

Taylor. Q. Did you not come into my shop, and represent yourself as the landlord? A. As acting for the landlord—you refused to let me see the pre
mises when I came—the neighbours said you had been stripping lead from this roof, and I came, and asked to see it—you said you had orders not to let any one see it.

Taylor's Defence. When I took this shop, this landlord had applied to the house of call for a hairdresser; I was directed to this house, and was kept till twelve o'clock; when Cameron came he wanted to detain the house, and to employ me in it; I did not like it; he allowed me the shop at 5s. a-week, and I was annoyed by one and another representing themselves as landlord; I left it, and had been out a day, and Cameron coaxed me back again; I came back in the morning of this transaction; I did not lodge in the place; I came in, and saw this van at the door; the landlord had told me the night before, that he had some men coming; he had lodged in the house, and that morning he asked me if I would lend a hand to these things; they were all in the passage; at first I refused, but he said he would pay me for so doing.
King's Defence. He came, and asked me to move a few things from the passage to the van, and I did so.
Watson's Defence. I went there, and found the landlord; he asked me to assist in moving these things; I had not been there above ten minutes before the policeman came.

JOHN KNOTT
re-examined. I have seen a person In the place, who said his name was Cameron.

TAYLOR—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

KING—
GUILTY . Aged 46.

WATSON—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

757.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Jan., 2 pictures and frames, value 5s., the goods of
Wilkinson Moore; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Three Months.

758.
GEORGE RATHBONE was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 12 shirts, value 1l. 1s., the goods of
Eliza Ann Plum.

EDWARD SULLINGS . I am in the employ of Mr. Peggs, a confectioner, in Whitechapel-road. On the 21st of Jan., about twelve o'clock at night, I was in the shop of Eliza Ann Plum—I saw the prisoner take twelve shirts from the counter, and throw them down outside, and two boys outside took them—one of them dropped the bundle—I ran, but did not take either of them—I took the prisoner in the shop.

CHARLOTTE PLUM . I live with my daughter Eliza Ann Plum, who keeps a hosier's shop in Whitechapel-road. There were three bundles taken—the other two are quite lost—I picked up the bundle that was dropped just out
side the door—I am quite sure these are my daughter's shirts.

Prisoner. I went to buy a shoe-lace, and while I was there, some one must have come in, and got these; there was no one outside; the lady left me at the door, and I did not move. Witness. I was in the act of giving him

change—I saw something, and ran to the door, and took this bundle up—I turned to the prisoner, and told him he was one of the boys, but I did not know that he was the one that took them—they had been on the opposite counter to me, about three yards from the door—the prisoner must have turned round to get them—there was no one in the shop but the prisoner and I—there had been another, but he went out before the prisoner came in.

EDWARD SULLINGS
re-examined. I ran after the other two, and Mrs. Plum detained the prisoner in the shop—I am sure I saw the prisoner move the bundle to the other two.

GUILTY . ** Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

759.
JOHN BOWEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Jan., 1 pocket-book, value 6d.; and I shilling; the property of
Jane Gottfred, from her person.

JANE GOTTFRED . On the afternoon of the 15th of Jan., I was in St. Andrew's Scotch Church, Philpot-street, Stepney—my gown was cut, and I lost several things out of my pocket, amongst which was a pocket-book, and a shilling in it—the prisoner sat next to me—this is my pocket-book, and this letter was in my pocket.
JAMES WHARF (police-constable K 57.) I had the prisoner the next day, in custody on two other charges—I found this pocket-book, and this letter on him.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

760.
THOMAS HIGGINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Jan., 1 till, value 1s.; 15 pence, 45 halfpence, and 65 farthings; the property of
William Birnie: and that he bad been before convicted of felony.

JOHN BALLAM . I am journeyman to Mr. William Birnie. On the 19th of Jan. I was in the bakehouse, and heard my mistress call—I ran up, ran out, and saw the prisoner running with the till under his arm—a witness stopped him—I came up and found the till on him—it was my master's, and there were pence, halfpence, and farthings in it.

WILLIAM DENNIS . I stopped the prisoner with the till under his arm—he was running as fast as he could—I asked where he got it—he said some boy brought it out of the shop and put it on bis head—I did not see any one but him.
JANET BIRNIE . This is my son's till—his name is William Birnie—I saw it safe that morning, and it contained pence, halfpence, and farthings.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going by, a young man stopped me, and said, "Here is a box, you may have what is in it;" I was going along, and a gen
tleman stopped me; this lady said she saw me in the shop; I was never in it in my life.
WILLIAM HIGH (police-constable K 242.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

761.
MARY BARNETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Jan., 1 counterpane, value 6s.; 1 sheet, 1s. 6d.; 1 table-cloth, 1s.; and 1 flat-iron, 6d.; the goods of
Ann Smith.

ANN SMITH . I live in Ashton-street, Poplar. The prisoner hired a room of me, and left on the 17th of Jan., without paying her rent—I missed my counterpane, sheet, table-cloth, and flat-iron on the 18th—these are them.
JOHN WILLIAM FORELAND . I am a pawnbroker. I have the sheet and counterpane—the counterpane was pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. A man who was living with me pawned the counterpane—I did
not go in with him. Witness. You pawned the counterpane while the man was at the door.
JAMES BENNETT . I am a pawnbroker. I have a table-cloth and flat-iron; to the best of my belief, the prisoner is the person who pawned them.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

762.
JAMES DONNELLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Jan., 1 pint and a half of gin, value 2s., the goods of
Richard Blake.

JANE BLAKE . I am the wife of Richard Blake—the prisoner was in my service. On the 31st of Jan. I came down in the morning, and my little boy told me something—I found a pewter pot and a stone bottle full of gin.

GEORGE BLAKE . I live with my parents. I saw the prisoner take two bottles off the end of the counter, draw a pint of gin, and put it into the bottles—I told my mother, and she found it under the counter.

Prisoner. I got the funnel from him; I was going to take it to the shop; I said I would pay for the gin when the money came; he gave me the bottles. Witness. He took the pot and drew the gin out of the tap on the counter—he saw I was watching him—I gave him the funnel.
NOT GUILTY .

763.
JOHN COLLINS and
JAMES WILLIAMS were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 16th of Jan., 330lbs. weight of pork, value 5l. 12s.; and 1 cask, 2s.; the goods of
John Hutley.

EDWARD HANSON . I am carman to Mr. John Hutley, a wholesale cheese
monger, in Broad-street, St. Giles's. I put out a cask of pork from half-past six to seven o'clock on the 16th of Jan.—I saw it safe about seven, and a little after eight it was missing—the pork was worth 5l. 12s., and the cask 2s.,—this is the cask—here is my master's mark on the head of it

WILLIAM CHADWICK (police-sergeant F 2.) I was on duty in High-street on the 16th of Jan., just before eight o'clock, nearly opposite the prosecu
tor's shop—I saw the prisoner Collins and another man go to the prose
cutor's shop, roll away a cask, and take it to the comer of George-street—they then went and spoke to Williams, who was walking up and down in sight of the prosecutor's shop—I am sure he was in sight of it when Collins and the other man were rolling the cask away—he did not touch it, but they left it and went and spoke to Williams—he walked to the shop, looked in, and then came to them again—then they commenced rolling it away—when they got to George-street, I saw a truck—Collins had hold of the bottom of the cask in the truck, and the other man had hold of the handle to pull it down—they then saw me—the other man ran away, and I caught hold of Collins, and asked what he was going to do with it—he said he did not know—I expect Williams was at that time against the shop.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had Williams anything with him? A. No—I had not seen him before.

WILLIAM CHADWICK . I am a police-inspector. I stopped Williams near the prosecutor's shop—I told him he must come to the station—he said he knew nothing about it—I had not said any thing to him previously.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been to Mr. Hutley's shop before you went to Williams? A. I had—I went and told him he must come with me to the station—that was directly after I came from the shop—he was about three or lour yards from the shop.

ELLEN REARDON . I keep an apple-stall opposite the prosecutor's shop. Williams came to me about a quarter-past seven o'clock—he said, "Did you see a wagon with eight horses?"—I said, "No"—he said he came up three times a week, and he wanted to take six of them—he put his hand on the cask, and then he put his foot, and rolled it a little—I did not see Collins.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Williams? A. No—I never saw him before—I have been sitting in that street about fifteen years—Williams was talking to me about ten minutes—there were not a great many persons about—I never told anybody what I had heard till next morning, when the shopkeeper asked me about it—when Williams pushed the cask, I went away—I generally stand in one place in St. Giles's—I was not there when the officer took Collins—I went away two or three minutes after Williams spoke to me.
STEPHEN CALCOTT . Collins hired a truck of me that evening.

Collins's Defence. I was coming along St. Giles's; a respectably dressed man told me to go to the Spur Inn, in the Borough, to fetch two boxes and a beds ead, for 2s.; I agreed to do it; I went and got the truck, and when we came to the corner of George-street, he said, "We will go and have a drop of gin;" we did, and then he said, "I have got a cask to leave on the road;" he left me with the gin, and was gone six or seven minutes, and when he called me the cask was at the tail of the truck; I was lifting it up, and when the man saw the policeman he ran away and left me; I never saw Williams till he was taken.

COLLINS—
GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.

WILLIAMS**—
GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Transported for Seven Years.

764.
ELEANOR HILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Jan., 1 blanket, value 5s.; and 3lbs. weight of feathers, 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Martha Capel.
MARTHA CAPEL . I am a widow, and live in Fox's-lane, Shadwell. The prisoner lodged with me, and left on the 13th of Jan.—I afterwards missed my blanket and these feathers—these are them.
JAMES MOODY . I live with Mr. Smaller, a pawnbroker. I produce a blanket, and some feathers in a pillow, pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. The blanket she gave me leave to pledge; she went by the name of Mrs. Collier.

MARTHA CAPEL
re-examined. I did not give her leave to pledge it—the prisoner ran away, and left the duplicate in a drawer—I went by the name of Collier when I took the house—I lived nearly twenty years with a person of that name, bnt my name is Capel.
NOT GUILTY .

765.
JOHN SCHMIDT was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Jan., 1 jacket, value 4s., the goods of
Nicholas Marquand; and 1 coat, 7s., the goods of
Robert Walton, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.
ROBERT WALTON . I belong to a schooner lying in the Regent-canal. The prisoner came alongside of it on the 31st of Jan.—I afterwards missed my coat and a jacket—this is my coat.
NICHOLAS MARQUAND . This is my jacket—it was on board the schooner.

GEORGE TUCKFIELD . I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner about half-past ten o'clock in the evening, on the 31st of Jan., with these things—I asked what he had got—he said it was all his own—I would not let him pass with them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

766.
WILLIAM HENNETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Jan., 1 pair of boots, value 17s., the goods of
David Jehu.

JOHN MARTIN BASS . I am servant to David Jehu, a shoemaker in Jamaica-terrace. On the 30th of Jan., I saw the prisoner peep three times, and the third time his mate unhooked a pair of boots, and gave them to the
prisoner—the prisoner ran to the bottom of the street—I followed, crying "Stop thief," and saw him throw the boots away—my master's son picked them up.
DAVID JEHU . These boots are my father's—I ran after the prisoner, and saw him throw them down.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw a pair of boots on the pavement, and the pro
secutor running down the street; I took them, and could not see the boy; I ran and put them down again.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

767.
FREDERICK BIGGS was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Jan., 3 printed books, value 4s. 9d., the goods of
Alfred Dormer Nash.
ANN DAVEY . I am shopwoman to Mr. Alfred Dormer Nash, bookseller, Seymour-street, St. Pancras. I missed these three books from outside my door—they were safe on the Saturday before they were lost.
JAMES HERSEY (police-constable S 144.) I produce these books, which I found on the prisoner last Tuesday.

Prisoner's Defence. I met two boys who I knew; they asked me to sell some books for them; I asked if they stole them; they said no; I went to a shop to sell them; they said they were no good, they were so old.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

768.
PHILLIP HIBBITT was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Dec., 1 box, value 6d.; 25 sovereigns, 100 crowns, 200 half-crowns, 300 shillings, 200 sixpences, and 300 groats; the property of
Benjamin Worthy Horne and another, his masters.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the property of
Joseph Roundtree.

JOHN CASSON . I live with Mr. Joseph Roundtree, a grocer, on the Pave
ment, at York. On the 27th of Dec, I sent a box to Mr. Stereker, of Budge-row, containing 75l. in silver, and 25l. in gold—I counted it myself, and saw it put into the box—the silver was wrapped in 10l. parcels—there were 3l. 10s. in fourpenny-pieces—it was all packed up in the box, and some shavings put into it—the box was about six inches long and five deep—I saw it corded, and directed the only card which was nailed on was to William Stere
ker, No. 13, Budge-row, London—I gave it to Christopher Robinson, to take to the railway station.

CHRISTOPHER ROBINSON . I am in the service of Mr. Roundtree, of the Pavement, York. On the 27th of Dec., a box was delivered to me by Cas
son—it was directed "William Stereker, Budge-row, London"—I nailed the lid on, and took it to the railway station.

HENRY RODGERS . I am passing-clerk of the York station. On the 27th of Dec., I received a box directed to Mr. Stereker—I entered it in the way-bill, "Box, Stereker"—this is the way-bill—I gave it to the guard of the carriage.

THOMAS BRAMLEY . I am guard of the York and North Midland train. I received the parcel to go to Budge-row, and this way-bill—I took the box of the clerk—I put it in the van, and locked it, to come to London.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you really remember that par
ticular box? A. Yes—it was Tuesday evening when I put it into the van—I was asked about it on Friday, at York.

JOHN COOPER . I am clerk of the parcels' office of the London and Bir
mingham Railway Company, Euston-square. The parcels are called over to me from the way-bill—I remember this way-bill being received on the 28th of
Dec.—I saw the name of "Stereker, box," on it—I wrote on it, Budge-row, according to the direction on the parcel.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the box yourself? A. I did not—I can
not say how many men were employed at the time this train came—perhaps there might be four or five men within the compass of three or four yards—all the parcels are pitched in a heap on the floor, and each man picks out his own—Mr. Davis is managing clerk for Messrs. Horne and Chaplin—I have beard that he refuses to take silver from the men.

JAMES SMITH . I am porter to the London and Birmingham Railway Com
pany at Euston-square. On the 28th of Dec. I was present when the parcels were called over which arrived by the train from York—they were handed to one of Home and Chaplin's men, (I do not remember which)—each of them fetch them away as they are called over.

JAMES THORGOOD . I am in the employ of Home and Chaplin, carriers. I live in Seymour-street, Euston-square—the prisoner was in their employ on the 28th of Dec.—I remember leaving the railway station at half-past seven o'clock that morning with the prisoner—we had a cart—there were parcels in the cart—the prisoner drove the horse, and I sat by his side—I remember a box being put in at Euston-square station, directed to Mr. Stereker, Budge-row—I sorted that with other parcels—the direction was nailed on with five tacks, and tied round with cord—it appeared to be a rather heavy box—the cart was driven to the Old Bailey—I remember there seeing the parcel—I left the cart to deliver a parcel in Prujean-square—I was gone about five or ten minutes—when I returned I found the cart was standing at Mr. Fenn's door, in Newgate-street—the prisoner was not with it, but standing at the corner of the Magpie and Stump—I asked why he left the cart—he said he left some one in charge of it—I did not see any one in charge of it—the prisoner and I then went to the cart—he asked if I would go and do something in Pater
noster-row, and I asked him to take a parcel to Fisher's, in Newgate-street—I left him in Newgate-street, and I took the cart to Paternoster-row—he ap
pointed to meet me at the corner of Queen-street, Cheapside—when I left him, he turned round to go towards the Magpie and Stump—when I got to Paternoster-row, I looked for the box, and it was gone—I had seen it in the cart when we stopped in the Old Bailey—after delivering the parcels in Paternoster-row I went to Queen-street, and saw the prisoner there—his brother and Cottrell were with him—I asked him whether we had not a parcel directed for Mr. Stereker, Budge-row—he said, "No, that was yesterday, or the morning before"—I said, "I think we had one this morning"—he did not go any further with the cart, he said he was not very well—he had had rather too much to drink, and he asked me if I would go with the cart—Cotterell was to go with me—it was the prisoner's duty to have gone through with the cart, and delivered the parcels with me—in the evening of that day I found, at the bottom of the cart, the direction of "Mr. Stereker, Budge-row"—I put it in the bottom of the cart again—the next morning I told the prisoner I had found a direction to Mr. Stereker, Budge-row—he said that was the name he had got one charged to in his book, and asked what I had done with the direction—I said I had left it at the bottom of the cart—he asked me to get it him—I told him I would, as soon as we got rid of some of the parcels—I found it the same morning, and gave it to the prisoner—he tore it up, and told me to swear that I never saw the parcel—on the Saturday I communicated this to my brother—I and he went to the railway station.

Cross-examined. Q. About how many parcels were there when you put them in the cart? A. Between fifty and sixty—this was rather a dirty box, the cord was tied round tight, I took particular notice of it—the direction

was nailed on with five nails—I did not hear the gentleman call out this par
cel—it was with the other parcels when I came to the station—it is a common thing, when we go out, for one to take a direction of two or three streets, and another some others—I delivered a box, wrapped round with cloth, at Pru-jean-square, and five or six parcels in Paternoster-row—none before I got there—I missed the box before that, on my first stopping—it had been on the right-hand side of the cart—there were other parcels by the side of it—it was standing on the top of parcels, there was nothing upon it—I found Cottrell in Queen-street, and the prisoner's brother—I did not hear Cottrell undertake to do the prisoner's work for him—he did do it—he was standing at the side of the horse when I asked the prisoner if we bad not a parcel for Budge-row—I said I could not see it in the cart—I missed it, but I was not certain whether the prisoner had taken it—I told him, "There is a parcel gone, that I am sure of"—we joined company again about four or five hours after, in Gray's Inn-road, and then he appeared to have recovered from his drunken
ness—the cart had one parcel in it then—Cottrell rode in the cart—I found the direction at the bottom of the cart, between two and three o'clock—Cot
trell got out a little after three—he was inside when I arrived at the Globe-inn, and then the cart was empty, except one parcel—I cannot say where Cottrell sat, because I was driving, and did not look round to see—he was not sitting by the side of me, he must have been inside, where this direction was—I did not go and tell any one, "Here is the direction of the box that is lost"—it was nine at night that I found it, when I was in Bishops
gate-street—on Friday, about three, Mr. Dawson, our superintendent, asked me something about it—I told him I did not know any thing about it—I did not tell about my finding a direction, and putting it back—I told my brother something on Saturday—there was a great stir about the negligence of the porter about this parcel—I told my brother, because I had told Mr. Dawson a falsehood about it—there was no straw at the bottom of the cart.
MR. PAYNE. Q. Why did you tell Mr. Dawson an untruth that you after-repented of? A. Because the prisoner told me I should get into trouble if I said anything.

GEORGE KENT . I am a blind-maker, living in Kensington-row, Gray's Inn-road. I went to the Pinder of Wakefield, in Gray's Inn-road for change—the landlady said she could not give it me—I got change from a man there—I cannot say exactly what it consisted of, but a great deal of it was fourpenny-pieces—the man who gave me change was in company with another—I should know the other man—I believe the prisoner is the man who gave me the change.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you undertake to swear to him? A. I will not.

WILLIAM STOWTON . I keep the Globe, in Darby-street, King's-cross. I remember, on Wednesday, the 28th of Dec., Thorogood coming from a cart with a man—he had some communication with the prisoner there, who had been there before—Barker was with him—they came between two and three o'clock—the prisoner was not sober—the prisoner asked me to change 2l. or 3l. worth of silver—I only took 1l.—there were 12s. or 14s. worth of four-penny-pieces among it—I said, "I have so many joes already, I won't take any more"—I gave one sovereign for 1l. of silver.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you take any fourpenny pieces? A. Not one—I saw them.

THOMAS BARKER . On the 28th of Dec. I went with the prisoner to the Pinder of Wakefield—he had 1l. worth of silver—I gave change for a sove
reign, because the landlady would not take it—I gave that 1l. worth of silver for the sovereign—the prisoner put the silver there—it consisted of shillings and 10s. or 11s. worth of fourpenny-pieces—we had been to the Globe before—we took them there because they would not take them at the Globe.
Cross-examined. Q. What was the whole amount of fourpenny-pieces? A. I think there were 10s. worth—I live in Greville-mews.

WILLIAM THOROGOOD . My brother made a communication to me, on Sa
turday, about something that had happened to Messrs. Chaplin and Horne, in consequence of which I went up to the station, and made a statement there.
JOHN SAVAGE . I keep the Rising Sun, in Somers-town. A. few days after Christmas I gave the prisoner a 5l. note, and he gave me 5l. of silver—there were no fourpenny-pieces among them.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. He has been in the habit of bringing me change all the last summer—I always thought him to be a well-conducted, honest man.
FREDERICK ALDHOUSE . I am clerk to Home and Chaplin. The prisoner paid me his accounts up to the 27th of Dec.—we always asked them to bring at much gold as they could.

BENJAMIN COTTRELL . I am porter at the Cross Keys, Wood-street. On the 28th of Dec. I drove the prisoner's cart—I first saw him between Wood-street and Milk-street—he was talking to somebody—he asked me to go with the cart and the boy—I refused to go at first, but afterwards consented, from the persuasion of the prisoner's brother—I went down Cheapside to the corner of Queen-street.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the reason the brother gave that he was not fit to do duty, as he had been drinking too much? A. Yes; he was intoxi
cated—it was very near ten o'clock in the morning—the boy did not say to me that he had lost a parcel.

JAMES BARRY . I am superintendent of the police of the London and Bir-mingham Railway. I took the prisoner, on the 2nd of Jan., at Mr. Horne's private house, in Bedford-row—he said he was very much distressed, and had pawned his watch to make up his accounts, which I afterwards found to be untrue—I found 2l. 10s. in gold, 1l. 0s. 2d. in silver, and some copper on him.

THOMAS THOROGOOD
re-examined. I do not think we took any fourpenny-pieces on the 28th—we do not generally get more than six or seven in a day—he had not drank anything with me on the road—he was quite sober when he got to the Old Bailey.
(Edward Way, of Sun-street, Bishopsgate; and—Ewell, potato-dealer, Pit field-street, Hoxton; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

769.
HENRY LONSDALE and
GEORGE ROBINS were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of Jan., 1 sixpence, the money of
Thomas Marriott, the master of Lonsdale.

ESTHER MARRIOTT . I am the wife of Thomas Marriott, and carry on business in High-street, Bloomsbury; Lonsdale was in our service, as bar
man for about three months. On the 26th of Dec. eight shillings and three sixpences, marked, were given to me by my husband, about five o'clock in the afternoon—I cleared the tills, and put the marked money in—I left the bar—there was 6s. 6d. in one till, and two shillings and two sixpences in the other—I saw Beresford, the inspector, in front of the bar after I put the money in—three customers came to the counter—I saw them served—I did not see what they had—after they were served, I ran to the tills, and there was no disturbance in the tills, and no increase—the silver was not moved—my at
tention was only drawn to the silver.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where was the copper? A. In a separate till by itself—it is the same drawer, but there are partitions.

HENRY BERESFORD . I am an inspector of the C division. On this day I went with a gentleman to the prosecutor's house, a few minutes before five o'clock, in consequence of a communication I had with him a few days before—I was in disguise—I had been in seven or eight minutes, when two persons came to the wholesale counter—one called for a glass of spirits—a quartern of liquor was drawn by Lonsdale—while he was serving them across the counter, directly he drew it, he whispered to them—one of them put down a shilling—he dropped it into the till—the moment the money was given—he gave a shilling back and some halfpence—Robins then came in—they were all three together—Lonsdale, without asking a question, or any thing being said on either side, took a small liquor-glass, drew it full, and set it on the counter—they were all close together—Robins put down a sixpence on the counter—Lonsdale took it up and dropped it into the till—he then put his left hand into the halfpence, shook them, and never looked at his hand at all, but put some halfpence down, and took out the sixpence, and laid it down beside them—Robins took them up, and as he left the bar, put them into his right hand trowsers pocket—I went out at another door close by, and seized him with his hand in his pocket—I found 6 3/4 d. in copper, and a sixpence on him—I then took Lonsdale—in going down Queen-street, Robins asked him whether he thought it would hurt his character, or whether he could get bail—he said, "Hold your tongue, you b----y fool; whatever you have to say, say it irt another place."

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you? A. In front of the bar—I had something to drink—Mr. Aldhouse, by my directions, called for it—I should say I was about three yards from where Robins was stand
ing—it is a cross counter, and comes to an angle—I had my eye directed to what was going on, I swear I saw this sixpence, given by Robins, put into the till—Lonsdale took the halfpence out with his left hand, and took the sixpence out with his right.
HENRY ALDHOUSE . I was there by direction of Mr. Beresford—I have heard what he has stated—it is correct.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Did Lonsdale ring the six-pence? A. No, he put it into the till directly—I believe it was laid on the counter, and taken up—I know he dropped it into the till—I saw him pick it up—it was laid on the counter, to the best of my knowledge.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you sure it was a sixpence that was given? A. Yes, I am sure it was not a shilling—I was three yards off.
NOT GUILTY .

770.
JAMES WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Jan., 4 shillings, the monies of
William Michael Davis.

ROBERT LINCOLN . I am in the service of William Michael Davis, of the Blue Posts, Berwick-street. I had been there seven months—I had been there when a man named Ashton was barman—he went away in Oct.—I had seen the prisoner there during the time Ashton was there—I knew him—I met him going up Broad-street, nearly three months before he was taken into cus
tody at the latter end of Oct.—he asked me if I wanted any money "worked" for me—I said no, I did not want any—he said it would be a great deal to my interest if I worked any—I said no, I never worked any, and did not wish to have any worked for me; that was all I said to him at that time, and we parted—I had heard "worked money" spoken of by my master, and had

read about it in the newspaper—I communicated to my master what had passed between me and the prisoner—about six weeks after my first conversation the prisoner came to my master's house—my master was in the bar at the time—he did not say anything then—on the 5th of Jan, my master gave me directions, in consequence of which I went to Lambeth-square, New-cut, where I thought I could find the prisoner—he was not in the way, am I wrote this note by my master's direction, and left it for him—(read—"Mr. Williams will greatly oblige me by calling on me at Mr. Davis's, Blue Posts, Berwick-street, as I have got a little business for you to do for me upon what you spoke to me about a little while ago")—I left it about five in the even
ing—about half-past seven he and his wife came to my master's house—I saw them outside the door—the prisoner came and patted me on the shoul
der—I said I did not expect to see him down so soon—he said directly he got the note he came down—I asked if he could come on Saturday evening—he said perhaps I could give him something that same evening—I said he could come in if he liked—he came in, and bought some liquor with a six-pence—I gave him the proper change—he came a second time the same even
ing—I drew him a glass of liquor—he put down a shilling, and said, "On to it now"—I did not give him any more money than he was entitled to then—on the following Sunday I saw him in the street, and walked with him along Compton-street, and down Covent Garden-market, into the Strand—I went to the Red Lion there, and had a conversation with him about Ashton—an arrangement was made between me and him that he was to come down that evening, and come in once or twice in the evening, and I was to give him what I could each time—he said he was to put down a shilling, I was to take it up, make a pretence of putting it into the till, take out two or three more, and place it on the counter, end he was to take it up, and if he was to come in again, I was to rub my arm, if not, I was to put out my finger—I told my master all that had passed—the prisoner came in twice during that evening—on the Monday he was to come again—I saw some money marked, and put into the till—he came between seven and eight in the evening—an officer was sent for—the officer had arrived when the prisoner first came in that evening—I did not give him any money the first time—he came in again and bought a pennyworth of gin—he put down a shilling—I then gave him four marked shillings, the shilling he gave me, and 3 1/2 d.—directly my hand was off it, he took it off the counter and put it into his right hand pocket, and was going to walk off with it, when he was seized by the officer.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You seem to know the mean
ing of working money? A. I had heard it spoken of many times in the house, not among the pot-boys, but by my master—it was the common talk of the shop before the prisoner mentioned it—my master spoke of it when he suspected Ashton of robbing him—he said he could not think how the money could be worked for him to lose the money he did by Ashton—I am quite sure he said that—I mentioned the conversation I had with the prisoner to my master the same day, and nothing further was done—I am not related to my master—I had not been a public-house boy before I lived with Mr. Davis—I was boots at an hotel—I never heard of working money till my own master told me what it was—none of the conversation between me and the prisoner took place in my master's house—the Red Lion is a house that the prisoner pro
posed to go to on the Sunday—there were several people standing in that house.

WILLIAM MICHAEL DAVIS . I am Lincoln's master. In consequence of information from him, I marked ten shillings on Monday, the 9th of Jan., and put them into the till—some of them were afterwards produced to me by
Beresford, the officer—Lincoln had previously made communications to me on the prisoner's propositions to him—he acted in this with my knowledge and consent, and by my directions.

Cross-examined. Q. You told him to do all that he has done? A. Yes—I gave him directions to give the prisoner the money in the way he has done—I do not recollect that I told him to write the letter, but I told him to call upon the prisoner and renew the connexion—I first heard from him about this some time in the month of Oct.—I cannot say the day—it was the day the prisoner communicated with him—it was between two and three months before the letter was written—I had not an opportunity of having anybody placed to hear any conversation between him and the prisoner, but after the first con
versation I felt an anxious wish to bring the prisoner to justice.

HENRY BERESFORD . I am an inspector of the C division of police. On the afternoon of the 9th of January I saw the boy Lincoln come out, and the pri
soner was standing at the corner of Compton-street—I went on the following evening to the house—the prisoner came in—I searched him, and found on him five shillings and some copper—the next morning he wanted to have some coffee—I said, "No, I must keep this money"—he said, "It is my own money, I brought out six shillings, and I changed one shilling"—when I first seized him I found the money in his pocket—I showed it to Mr. Davis, and he identified four shillings of it as his money—the prisoner had just got to the door, when I seized him—he was not out.

Cross-examined. Q. And in fact he had got the money in bis hand? A. It was in his pocket—he had his hand in his pocket—I took his hand out and put my hand in, and took the money—I cannot say whether his hand was closed—I told him to take his hand out—I watched him all the time—when he received the money from the boy he closed his hand upon it, and put it into his pocket—I found on him the five shillings and 6 1/2 d. in copper.
MR. DAVIS re-examined. These are four of the shillings I marked and put into the till with six others, which I have in my pocket.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
771.
HENRY BAKER was indicted
for assaulting
John Blundell, an officer of police, in the execution of his duty;to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Four Months.

772.
AMELIA GILLINGS was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.

JANE ANN SHEPHERD . I am barmaid at the Dover Castle, in St. George's in the East, which is kept by Mr. Abraham Watson. The prisoner came there on the 6th of Jan., about half-past eight o'clock (I never saw her be
fore)—she said, "I want half a pint of gin and a pot of porter for Mr. Mace, next door to the baker's shop"—I served her—she came again, and said she wanted another half-pint of gin and a pot of porter for Mr. Mace, who was out, and as soon as he came in he would send over the money, and she had it—she came again for another half-pint of gin and another pot of beer—I let her have it—I saw Mr. Mace afterwards—the next morning I saw the prisoner come with the empty pots—I asked her how she came to come for the gin and porter for Mr. Mace, when he did not send her—she said she knew Mr. Mace did not send, but a gentleman whom he knew did.

JOHN MACE . I am a lighterman, and live at No. 27, Church-row, oppo
site the Dover Castle—I deal there for beer—I don't know the prisoner—I did not send her there for gin or beer on the 6th of Jan.

GEORGE CARR (police-constable K 166.) I was sent for to the Dover Castle on the 7th of Jan.—I received the prisoner in custody—as we were going along she said she had fetched the things, and intended to pay for them at dinner time; that Mr. Mace did not send her, hut a friend of his did—I said, "Who was that friend?"—she said, "I will not tell—I fetched it myself, and I don't wish to get any body else into trouble."
Prisoner. I am very sorry for what I have done. I had but 2s. for it

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Month.

773.
HENRY HUNT was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 2lbs. of beef steaks by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

774.
PHILIP GRIFFITHS was indicted
for assaulting
Stephen Gibbs and
William Munns, on the 4th of Nov., with intent to stab, cut, and wound them, to prevent his (the prisoner's) lawful apprehension.—2nd COUNT, stating his intent to be to do some grievous bodily harm.

STEPHEN GIBBS . I am game-keeper to Mr. Anderton.
