I was employed at South Mimms on a manor belonging to the Marquis of Salisbury, but let to Mr. Anderton—I was at Furzefield-wood on the 4th of Nov.—I saw the prisoner cutting the underwood—there was a great quantity of it cut and lying on each side of where he was—it was worth 1s. 6d. or 2s.—Munns was with me—we came up to the prisoner—he ran into the wood—we ran after him—before I got up the prisoner struck Munns with a stick, and knocked his hat off—I came up and said, "Philip, is that you?"—he said yes, and he would rip me up with a knife—he struck at me—I fell back, and the knife ran up my waistcoat and jacket and touched my chin, but it did not enter my flesh, nor fetch blood—he then took up a brick and threw it at me—he made several attempts at us with hit knife, but we kept him off with our sticks—he said he would stab the first man that came near him; and as I knew him I thought it would be as well to let him go, and not to run any further danger.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. What time of night was this? A. From half-past five to six—it was dark—the prisoner was thirty yards off when I first saw him—he was cutting the birch—it was getting dusk, but was not dark—I saw it was a man with a white smock on, and I knew him as soon as I got near him, before any thing took place. Munns went one way and I the other—it was all thin wood—we could see him all along—I had a stick in my hand—I struck him with my stick, to try to knock the knife out of his hand, after he had tried to stab me—he attempted to stab Munns, and then I ran up and tried to get the knife out of his hand—I did not strike him before he used the expression of ripping me up—we after
wards followed him on further—I asked where he lived; he said he had no home—I knew he lived in the village—he kept running one way and another, and swore he would rip us up—we were obliged to keep him off with sticks—the wood is composed of birch and oak—there might be acorns about, but no one has any right there—Mr. Warby rents the wood of the Marquis of Salisbury, and lets it to my master—it does not belong to Mr. White—his grounds are round the wood—a person passing through the wood might go to Mr. White's, but we allow no one to go through.

MR. HOWORTH. Q. This was on the 4th of Nov.? A. Yes, from half-past five to six o'clock—it was getting dusk—I did not know who the person was at first—I am quite sure I did not lose sight of him till I came up with him and Munns—I am sure the person I saw cutting the wood was

the prisoner—there is no foot-path through the wood to Mr. White's—I did not strike the prisoner with the stick, till after he attempted to stab me with the knife, which was after Munns had let him go—he was attempting to stab Munns in the face.

WILLIAM MUNNS . I was in Furzefield-wood on the 4th of November with Gibbs—I saw a person, and in consequence of what Gibbs said, I ran after the person—he got out of the wood, but I did not lose sight of him—I over
took him—it was the prisoner—he had a stick in his hand—he struck at me—I put my arm up, and he knocked my hat off—I ran up to him, and got the stick out of his hand—I got behind him—he got a knife out of his pocket, and said, if I did not let go of him, he would run it into me—he struck at me six or seven times—I kept behind him, and got hold of his arm—Gibbs came up, and said, "Is it you, Philip?"—he said, "Yes," and then I let him go—he attempted to stab him, and I knocked him off—he said he would not be taken by anybody—he got out of the field over the hedge, took a brick and threw it at Gibbs—I saw Gibbs hit him on the arm in the field, and try to knock the knife out of his hand—after he got over the hedge, and threw the brick, I said to Gibbs, "It is not worth while to run the risk of our lives; you know him."

Cross-examined. Q. What time was this? A. About half-past five, or from that to six o'clock—the prisoner was about forty yards off when we first saw him—I could see at that distance what he was about—after I went up to him, Gibbs came up, and addressed him by his name—I let him go—he walked away, and we pursued him again—it was after we came up to him again that Gibbs struck him on the arm—he had attempted to stab me and Gibbs—he walked away a little, and Gibbs said he should go to Mimms
cage—he said he would not be taken by anybody—Gibbs did not strike him before he had attempted to stab him—Gibbs held his stick up before him, he then made a stab at him, and then Gibbs hit him with the stick.
MR. HOWORTH. Q. Did he still keep the knife in his hand? A. Yes, and kept threatening us, as I have stated.

CARTER FAREBROTHER . I am land-steward to the Marquis of Salisbury—Furzefield-wood belongs to the Marquis. Gibbs is employed as game
keeper of that manor—I gave him directions to look to the underwood, and see that no damage was done, that no person cut any or took it away, and to detect a person who was doing so—I authorised him to detect any person whom he might find there—I had authority from his lordship to do so—that manor is under my control.

Cross-examined. Q. This wood is in the occupation of the Marquis of Salisbury? A. It is—Mr. White is the tenant of the farm, but not of the wood—his land is on one side—a person coming from Mr. White's might come through the wood by trespass—there is no footpath—I gave Gibbs authority to watch the wood, in a verbal manner and in writing.

STEPHEN GIBBS
re-examined. Q. Did you receive an authority in writ
ing from Mr. Farebrother? A. Yes—I really do not know what has become of it—I searched for it, and could not find it.

Cross-examined. Q. How long is it since you received that written authority? A. I think it must be twelve months ago—I should think it has been lost these six weeks—I had an authority when this took place—it was lying on the mantel-piece then, but it got knocked down by the children, and got burnt—I did not see it burnt—the woman where I lodge said so—I did not expect it would be asked for—I searched for it a day or two after the case was before the Magistrate.
MR. HOWORTH. Q. You were asked for it? A. Yes—I went home and asked mistress for it, and could not find it.

GUILTY on the second Count. Aged 29.—
Confined Six Month.

775.
HANNAH PEARTON was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.

JAMES OSBORNE . I am shopman to John Fox Kemp, a grocer, at Uxbridge. I did not know the prisoner till she came on the 31st of Jan., about one o'clock, and said she wanted 1/2lb. of black tea and 1/4lb. of green tea, 2lbs. of butter, 61bs. of sugar, half a bar of soap, and 1/2lb. of tobacco, for Mr. Stilwell—I asked if it was for Mr. Arthur Stilwell—the said it was for Mr. Arthur Stilwell, of Moorcroft-house—I knew him, and then asked if she had brought the book—she said she had not, but she requested a bill, which I made out—she took the goods, went away, and left the bill on the counter—after she was gone I had some suspicion—I sent Gutteridge after her.

WILLIAM GUTTERIDGE . I am shopman to Mr. Kemp. I was sent after the prisoner—I had seen Osborne serve her—she is the person—I went to Mr. Stilwell's, and then after the prisoner—I knew where she lived—I knocked, and she came to the door—I asked her if she had been to Uxbridge—she denied having been there at all—I went to the house again with the officer—I asked her if she had been to Uxbridge—she said she had—her father asked her where the goods were—she brought them down stairs, and I gave her in charge.

GEORGE GODFREY . I am a constable. I went with Gutteridge to the prisoner's—Gutteridge asked if she had been to Uxbridge—the said, "Yes"—he asked if she had been, and got these goods by false pretence—the said, "Yes"—we asked her where they were—she said, up stairs in her bed-room, and she brought them down, and they were delivered to me.
JAMES OSBORNE re-examined. These goods are my master's.
ARTHUR STILWELL . I live at Moorcroft-house, Uxbridge. The prisoner was in our service six years ago—I did not send her for these article—they were not sent for for my house at all.
Prisoner. I am very sorry; I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Months.

776.
SARAH GRIFFITHS was indicted
for unlawfully concealing the birth of a child.—2nd Count, charging her with unlawfully disposing of the dead body of the said child.

GUILTY on the 2nd Count. —Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

777.
BENJAMIN HAYCOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 11s., the goods of
Stephen Woodcock.

STEPHEN WOODCOCK . I keep a shoe-shop on Great Saffron-hill. On the evening of the 2nd of Feb., the prisoner came with three other persons, one of whom was named Simpson, who came for a pair of shoes he had left to be mended—I attended to him, and after that the prisoner asked me to measure him for shoes—I measured him, and then one of the others—the prisoner then left the shop, and my daughter told me something—I had missed a pair of boots from my door—I went, and found the prisoner in the White Horse—I accused him of stealing a pair of boots—he denied it—I said I would fetch my daughter—he then slipped off his jacket, and put it on the settle—I gave charge of him—I afterwards saw the boots in the officer's hand.

CHARLOTTE ELIZABETH WOODCOCK . I am six years of age. I know the necessity of speaking the truth—I remember the prisoner coming to my father's, while my father was measuring Spriggins—the prisoner had these boots in his
hand, which were hanging inside the door—I did not see what he did with them—he left the shop—I saw him put them under his jacket.
JOHN MARTIN . I live next door to the White Horse. I was in the yard between six and seven o'clock in the evening, on the 2nd of Feb.—I found this pair of boots on the wall.

CHARLES ELLIOTT (police-constable G 139.) I saw the boots in the pos
session of Martin—I took the prisoner into custody.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
778.
THOMAS WHITEHEAD was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of Jan., 2 trusses of hay, value 5s., the goods of
John Miller, his master; and
BENJAMIN SPICER
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOHN PARSFIELD . I live in Church-street, Lisson-grove, next door to Mr. Miller, who deals in corn and hay—Whitehead has been in his employ for the last month—on Wednesday evening, the 18th of Jan., I saw him take a truss of clover hay out of Mr. Miller's barn, and put it down against Spicer's door, who lives in Duke-mews, next door but one to Miller's stable—Spicer was standing at his door at the time—I made my way towards them—they appeared to be in conversation—I said to Whitehead, "Tom, I think I shall go and get a pint of beer"—Whitehead then made his way from Spicer's, and I could neither see the clover, nor Spicer—I did not go to get any beer, but went and stood at the corner—I then saw Whitehead come again out of the barn with a truss of bent hay on his shoulder, which he took to Spicer's door—I then saw Spicer bring the truss of bent hay from the door up into Earl-street—I saw Spicer's man with the truss of clover hay on his back—I went to Mr. Miller's shopman, and told him what I had seen.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see Spicer at the door? A. No, I do not know where he was then—I was standing at the corner of Duke's-mews, and in about five or six minutes I saw Spicer with the bent hay on his back—he came from the door with it—I did not see him take it from the door—I did riot see him take it up—I had seen Spicer's man with a truss before that.
MR. PAYNE. Q. How near was Spicer to his own door? A. About five or six yards off.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON (police-sergeant D 4.) On Saturday night, the 21st of Jan., I went to Mr. Miller's counting-house, in consequence of information—Whitehead came into the counting-house while I was there—I said I was going to take him into custody—he asked what for—I said, "For stealing a truss of clover, and a truss of bent hay"—he said, "Why you asto
nish me"—he asked when—I said, "On Wednesday night"—he then said, "I know nothing about it"—I said he need not say any thing, I had a witness who saw him take two trusses from his master's to Spicer's door—he then said, "I will tell you the truth; I did take them to Spicer's, and Spicer re
ceived them"—on the road to the station, he said Spicer had been round to him that evening, and asked if he could have four or five more trusses, and he (Whitehead) told him he could not let him have them, but Spicer was in the habit of having a good deal of loose hay—I took him to the station, and

he returned to No. 2, Duke's-mews, where Spicer lives—I went up stairs, and found him in bed—I told him to get up, Mr. Miller wanted him—he asked his wife if she had paid for the oats and chaff that night—I said it was not about the oats and chaff that I took him, but on suspicion of receiving a truss of clover, and a truss of bent hay—he said he had bad no hay, and did not know Mr. Miller's man—I said a wit
ness saw him, and saw the hay come to his door, that Whitehead said he had taken the hay to him, and he had received it—he said he did not, he never had any hay of him—I said Whitehead had told me that he had been round that evening to know if he would let him have four or five more trusses—he said he had not been to Whitehead, and had not seen him—I took him to the station, and the two prisoners were there together—the inspector asked him, and Spicer said he knew nothing about it—Whitehead said something which I did not hear—Spicer then said, "Is that them? I will pay Mr. Miller for them if he will go next door, the money lies there"—I was present when the depo
sitions were taken—that is Mr. Rawlinson's signature to this deposition—they were all signed in my presence—(read)—"The prisoner Spicer says, 'I sever received them, and have not had a truss of hay in my place for three weeks.' J. RAWLINSON."

JOHN MILLER . I am a corn-dealer, and live in Lisson-grove North. Whitehead was a chaff-cutter, and helper in my service—he had no authority to take any clover hay, or bent hay, without my order, or that of my shop
man.
Cross-examined. Q. Is this where your business is carried on? A. Yes, in this stable, at the back of my house.
CHARLES WARD . I am shopman to the prosecutor. I did not authorise Whitehead to take these trusses of hay.
Whitehead's Defence. The keys of the warehouse are left with me ill day, and when the carters come at any time I serve then; sometimes I get an order, and sometimes not.

WHITEHEAD—
GUILTY . Aged 40,—
Confined Six Months.

SPICER—
GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Twelve Months.

779.
WILLIAM JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Jan., 20 handkerchiefs, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Scope Fowler.—2nd Count, stating it to be 8 yards of silk; and that he been before convicted of felony.

ROBERT MILLER . I am in the employ of Mr. Scope Fowler. On the 27th of Jan., about nine o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came into his shop—I showed him some shirt-collars; he bought one and paid for it—I had some silk handerchiefs there—I saw him take them, and put them under a coat which he had on hts arm—he went out—I ran and saw him—I lost sight of him—I then got sight of him again, and then he had neither count nor hand
kerchiefs—he had an opportunity of parting with them—there were twenty of them.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Yes, I had seen him about the street—I followed him to Regent-street—the turn
ing which leads to Regent-street is three or four yards from my master's shop—I followed him directly—he had got to the corner of Maddox-street—he was standing at the corner these, and I went to him—I can swear to him.
JOHN EDWARD RICHARDS . I was going up Regent-street, and saw the prisoner with a coat on his arm, and something red underneath it.
GEORGE TREW (police-constable H 125.) I produce a certificate of the
prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person who was convicted by the name of William Trott.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Seven Years.

780.
MARY FORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Jan., 25 yards of Orleans cloth, value 12s. 6d., the goods of
Henry Lee.

JOHN WITTLE . I am shopman to Mr. Henry Lee, a linendraper, in Leather-lane. About five o'clock in the evening, on the 20th of Jan., I missed 25 yards of Orleans cloth from inside the door—I went, and saw the prisoner standing outside, near the door—I gave her into custody.

JOSEPH BAILEY . I live in Upper North-place, Gray's-inn-road. About five o'clock that evening I saw the prisoner and another woman standing at the corner of the prosecutor's shop, at the corner of Baldwin's-gardens—the prisoner took the cloth from the right-hand side of the door, and gave it to the other woman—I am sure the prisoner is the woman that took it—I went into the shop, and the other woman was gone.
Prisoner. Q. Did you touch me on the back? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. He touched me on the back, and said, "I saw you take something, and give it to that woman, who is gone across the road;" I said, "If you saw a woman go across the road, why did you not stop her?"

GUILTY . * Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

781.
JAMES JONES and
WILLIAM KEEFE were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 25th of Jan., 12 cigars, value 3s., the goods of
William Henry Johnson: and
ALFRED ARNOLD
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM HENRY JOHNSON . I am a tobacconist, and live in Oxford-street. About ten o'clock on Wednesday morning, the 25th of Jan., Jones and Keefe came into my shop—Jones drew open the lid of a box on the counter, and took out twelve cigars, which he passed over to Keefe—Keefe put them into his coat, and ran away—I took Jones into custody—they had not asked for any cigars—when I went into the shop they asked for a pennyworth of tobacco—I am sure I saw Jones pass them over to Keefe.

GEORGE BECK . On Wednesday morning, the 25th of Jan., I was in a coffee-shop in Bell-street. Arnold was there—Keefe came in, and said, "Do you want to buy some cigars?"—Arnold said, "Let me look; I will buy them, as many as you have got"—Keefe took them out of his pocket, and said, "Here they are then"—Arnold took them into the parlour, and brought him out some halfpence, about 5d. I think there was—he said they were a half
penny a-piece.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You take a cigar at a coffee-shop, like other young gentlemen? A. Not unless I buy it—I do not buy them in a coffee-shop at all—I am fifteen years old—I pay 1d. a piece for them—I do not get them at three for 2d.—I have been here before about two old pairs of shoes—two boys got me into it—I have never been in custody but then—I was in the coffee-shop having a drop of coffee—I help my father at printing—it was a quarter past ten o'clock when I was at the coffee-shop—I saw Keefe and a boy named Nickaby there—I do not know what has become of Nickaby—the officer did not speak to me about this—he went to my father, and acquainted him that I was in bad company—that was on Wednesday night—he took me home to my father, and asked me where Keefe was—that was the first time I said anything about this—I remained in the coffee-shop about an hour that morning before I went home to my father—I dined with him, but said nothing about this.
JOHN GUYATT . I am an errand-boy. I met Hall, the constable, about

six o'clock, on that Wednesday evening—he asked me about Keefe—I went to the coffee-shop, where Arnold is waiter, and Keefe was sitting at the table—I went and told Hall that Keefe was there—I then went back into the house—as I was going in, Arnold came out, and met the constable, who Cold him he wanted Keefe—Arnold then came in, and told Keefe that Hall wanted him, and he was to go out at the back door and scale the wall.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you been in the coffee-shop? A. I only went in to see if Keefe was there—I am not acquainted with the con
stable, but he knew me by sight—he met me in the street that day—I go to Colonel Berners' to clean knives and shoes.

JOHN HALL (police-constable D 64.) From information I received, I went on Thursday night to a lodging-house, and found Keefe in bed—I said I wanted him, for stealing some cigars in Oxford-street—he said he knew no
thing about it—on the way to the station, he said he had met Jones in Oxford-street, at Mr. Johnson's shop; that he went in to buy a penny-worth of to
oacco, then jumped up behind a carriage, and went away—I met Guyatt, and asked if he knew Keefe—he went into the coffee-shop, and said he was there.

ROBERT JACKSON (police-sergeant D 25.) I took Arnold, for receiving cigars from Keefe—he said he had not received them—on the way to the station, he said he had received two eigars of Keefe, which he had smoked.
Cross-examined. Q. When was that? A. He did not mention the time—I told him, of course, the circumstances.

Keefe's Defence. I was coming along the street, and saw Jones coming out of the shop; he spoke to another boy; Jones said to me, "Stop, I am going home;" there was a carriage going by; I got on it, and rode away, as I wanted to make haste.

MARY ANN HARDIE . My husband keeps this coffee-shop—we do not dwell there—we dwell at No. 22, Winchester-street. I was in the coffee-shop on that Wednesday morning about seven o'clock—we have a parlour there, divided from the shop by a partition and door, with a window in the door and partition—I was in the parlour—I remember on that occasion some boys being there—Arnold was in the parlour—he went into the shop when the boys came in, to take the order—he came back to me in a few minutes—he had not taken any money then—I had seen no transaction between the boys and Arnold—if there had been I must have heard it.

COURT. Q. Are you related to Arnold? A. No, he is a friend of ours, we have known him some time—I swear he is not related to us—I have known him above twelve months, I dare say—he was in business, something in the straw line—we have kept this coffee-shop about two months—we live just by—it is a night-house, open all night—there are boys come there some
times—my husband's name is Charles—the shop is in Bell-street, Paddington.

Re-examined. Q. Do you remember some boys coming into the shop between eight and nine o'clock, in the evening, at the time Hall the policeman came? A. There were some boys came that evening—it might be about that time—I remember the policeman coming—Arnold was in the parlour—a boy came in, and said to Keefe, I think it was, "Hall wants you"—Arnold was then gone outside—Keefe got up immediately, and ran through the side-door into the street—Arnold was outside, talking to Hall—Hall then came in, he searched for the boy, and said to Arnold, "You have let him go"—Arnold said, "I have not let him go"—on the Friday following, two policemen came, and called for Arnold—I did not hear what they said.

THOMAS HENRY STOVEL . I am a biscuit-baker, and live in Winchester
row. On the 26th of Jan. I was at Hardie's coffee-shop, about eight o'clock in the evening—I went to take a cup of coffee—a boy came in, and

said to Keefe, "Hall is after you"—Keefe rose from his seat, and went from the shop into the parlour, opened the door, cut into the passage and out into the street, and escaped—Arnold was not in the shop.
COURT. Q. Do you attend this shop much? A. No, I have been in three or four times—it is a day and a night shop.
(Thomas Stevens, a boot-maker; and James Charlton, a watchmaker, in Lisson-grove, gave Arnold a good character.)

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

KEEFE*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

ARNOLD—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

782.
CHARLES SHIPLEY was indicted
for embezzling, on the 7th of January, 1 300l., 1 100l., 1 10l., and 1 5l. Bank-notes, and 10 sovereign, 10 half-sovereigns, 10 crowns, 10 half-crowns, and 10 shillings, the property of
Robert Williams, his master.—2nd Count, alleging the property to be in the possession of the said
Robert Williams and others; to which he pleaded

788.
NATHAN DANIELS was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan., 4 1/2 lbs. weight of solder, value 3s.; 1 metal cock, 5d.; 5 lbs. weight of copper, 1s.; 2 hammers, 6d.; 1 chisel, 6d.; 1 screwdriver, 6d.; 500 nails, 5d.; and 1 ornament, 1d., the property of
Asher Prior, his master.

JOHN MORE . About half-past five in the evening of 23rd of Jan., I wanted a pair of pliers, I went to the shop, and saw the prisoner with his tool-basket between his feet—I said, "I want a pair of pliers," and put my hand on his basket—he put his hand on it, and said, "They are not here"—I thought there was something wrong—I said, "Let us see what you have got here?"—I took the basket, and found these things in it—I said, "How do you account for this?"—he said, he did not know, be supposed some one must have put them into his basket—they belong to Mr. Asher Prior—this hammer was found at the prisoner's house afterwards—I swear these other things are Mr. Prior's.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you find the pliers there? A. Yes; he said he supposed some one must have put them in for a trap for him—this hammer has the mark of" A. Prior" on it—Mr. Prior is an ironmonger, and sells these articles—I swear to this packet of nails—there is Mr. Prior's son's writing on them, and we have never sold any to the prisoner—we have sold some—I found them in a box on the landing of the first floor—he was a lodger in the house—his wife said it was his box.

COURT. Q. What was found in the house? A. The hammer, screw
driver, and the chisel—I will swear they are Mr. Asher Prior's—I saw then safe about three months ago—the prisoner told an officer in my presence, that be lodged at No. 18, Claremont-place—I went there and found the box con
taining these articles—there were no other lodgers that come to my master's, that I am aware of.
TIMOTHY PRIOR . I have examined these articles, they are my brother's.
WILLIAM RANDALL PRIOR . These are not the tools I sold the prisoner eighteen months ago.

JOHN CAYFORD (police-constable E 97.) I was called to take the pri
soner—I went to his house and found the hammers, the chisel, screw
driver, and nails in a box, on the landing—the prisoner directed me to go to this house.
NOT GUILTY .

784.
NATHAN DANIELS
was again incicted for stealing, on the 2nd of Nov., 1 bottle-jack, value 7s., the goods of
Asher Prior, his master.
JOHN MOORE . I am shopman to Asher Prior—we had missed a bottle-jack—I have examined this, and believe it to be my master's—the duplicate of it was found on the prisoner at the station.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you say when you lost it? A. No.
JOHN BAGULEY . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this bottle-jack, on the 2nd of Nov.—I have a corresponding duplicate—the jack appears quite new.

GUILTY. Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined Nine Days.

785.
GEORGE BROOKS and
GEORGE MAYS were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of Jan., 1 tea-pot, value 10s.; the goods of
Henry Jones.

HENRY JONES . I live in Rose-street, King-street, Covent-garden. About half-past six o'clock, on the 26th of Jan., I was standing at the door, and saw Brooks pass—I went into the counting-house, and heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I went and saw the prisoners in custody, with this tea-pot—I believe it to be mine.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is there anything you know It by? A. I have missed such an one.

RICHARD JONES . I heard the cry of "Stop thief"—I ran out—the two persons passed me, from the staircase inside the house—I immediately fol
lowed—I lost sight of Mays and followed Brooks—I am sure he was one—when Brooks got into New-street he stumbled, and this tea-pot fell from his hand—I took it up and gave it to the policeman—I believe Mays to be the other man—he resembles him in every respect—he had a frock-coat on—I did not see his face.

SAMUEL SALDER . Between half-past six and seven o'clock, I was passing up New-street, and heard a cry of "Stop thief"—in a few minutes, the prisoners brushed past me—I stopped Mays—Brooks stumbled, and a blue bag fell from him—nobody but them were running—they were hatf-a-dozen yards from the prosecutor's house.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A clerk out of employ. I lodge in Dorset-street, Salisbury-square. I have been out of employ three months—my last place was with a hosier, in Brewer-street—I lived there four years—I left because I had a quarrel, not on a charge of dishonesty—I do not recollect exactly what it was.
(The prisoners received a good character.)

MAYS—
GUILTY . Aged 19. BROOKS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

786.
MARY BURNS was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of Jan., 1 ring, value 10s.; 1 buckle, 4s.; 1 brooch, 7s.; and 1 waistband, 1s.; the goods of
James Dowley: and
MARGARET BURNS
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

CAROLINE DOWLEY . I live with my father, James Dowley. The prisoner Mary was in the habit of coming to clean my house—I saw these articles safe on the 6th of Jan. and missed them on the 17th—these are them—I can swear to them—I charged Mary with taking them—she said she never saw them, nor pawned them—Margaret never came to the house.

JOHN WILLIAM FORELAND . I am a pawnbroker. Margaret brought this ring to me, and asked if it was gold—I said it was—she asked if I would buy it—I said, "No"—I said the watchmaker's was the best place—Mary and another girl afterwards came and asked whether they were gold—I said I saw
them a night or two ago—she said, "My mother brought them"—the ring is worth 1s. 6d.
CATHERINE GREEN . I searched Margaret and found this waisband, brooch, and buckle in her bosom—I found nothing on Mary.
Mary's Defence. I was sweeping the floor; they were in the dust; I thought they were of no use.
Margaret's Defence. She brought them home; I said, "Where did you get them"—she said she picked them up—they were in the house a week.
NOT GUILTY .

787.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Jan., 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Hitchcock, from his person.

THOMAS HITCHCOCK . I live in Frith-street, Soho. About three o'clock on the 31st of Jan., I was in Titchfield-street, and had occasion to stop at a dead wall—I felt a twitch at my pocket—I turned my head and saw the pri
soner with my handkerchief in his hand-he started off—I followed him, crying, "Stop thief"—he was stopped sixty or seventy yards up the street, and he threw the handkerchief down—I am sure he is the person-there are no marks on it—I had it not a minute before—it corresponds with mine in every respect.
Prisoner. Q. Did I have it in my hand? A. Yes, in your hand.

Prisoner. I was coming to Crown-street with a message; I was past the time, ran fast, and struck the gentleman with my left hand; the handker
chief was never found on me; I never touched it; there was nobody in the street, but there were two lads who followed the prosecutor.
THOMAS HITCHCOCK . No such thing, there was no one in the street.

GUILTY . * Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

788.
JAMES PILCHER was indicted
for embezzlement.

ALEXANDER ARCHIBALD . I am an accountant, residing in Southampton-row Edgeware-road, Marylebone. The prisoner was one of my clerks for twelve months—it was his duty to collect debts for various persons who employed me-it was his duty to enter what he received in the cash-book when he returned, and to account to me every evening-if he did not come Home that night, then the next morning-I engaged him to collect some money from Mr. Cripps, a staymaker, in Hanway-street—this is the book in which he made his entries—if he received 30s. on the 31st of May from Mr. Cripps, he has only accounted to me for 1l. he has not accounted to me for 1l. 10s. received from Mr. Cripps on the 6th of June—he has only accounted for 1l., and on the 28th of July, only for 10s.—in consequence of something that occurred on the 24th of Dec., I gave the prisoner into custody—I brought the policeman into my office, and said, "I give this man in charge for embez
zlemen"—he said, "Give me a littele time, and I will settle it"—I said, "No, Mr. Pilcher, I have told you of this before; this is the third time, and nobody will employ me if I do not punish you"—he said, "For the sake of my family, will you not arrange it?"—I said, "It does not admit of arrangement; I cannot do it."

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. There were some terms entered into with you and the prisoner, at the time you engaged him? A. he depo
sited 30l. in my hands—there was a writing signed—that sum was paid as security for any deficiency there might be in his accounts—this paper is drawn up by the prisoner, and signed by himself—(read)—"Mr. James Pilcher agrees to serve Mr. Archilbld as his clerk, and make himself generally useful, for three years, at 52l. per annum, paid weekly; hours of attendance, from

nine o'clock in the morning till eight in the evening; reasonable time to be allowed for meals. Mr. Pitcher's executors and guardians place in the hands of Mr. Archibald's banker, the sum of 30l., for any default in the accounts by Mr. Pilcher, or for penalty, should he be engaged by other persons, and the same sum of 30l., and interest, to be returned to Mr. Pilcher, provided his accounts are correct, otherwise such part of the 30l. to be appropriated in liquidation of the same. Mr. Pilcher to be allowed a commission on all busi-ness he may bring to Mr. Archibald."

Q. Was that 30l. paid in? A. Yes, and I have it still at my banker's—I have never paid the interest, it has never been settled about that—the 30l. if paid in at my banker's, as my money—I do not know whether all these entries in this book are in the prisoner's handwriting—whatever cash he re
ceived himself he entered, and what other clerks paid him over he entered—it may be that some of the others have entered it, but he was the cashier—on 31st of May, 6th of June, and 28th of July—he had ten or twelve people in a day to call on to receive money—they were all small sums—they were entered every day—they were never in arrears beyond the next morning—I have lived at my present residence about five years—I have been an accountant for twenty years—I was a man of property before—when I first came to London I commenced as commission-agent—I was a blue-manufacturer—I was a bankrupt ten years ago, as a coal-merchant and bill-broker—I got my certificate six or seven years after—I have not been in any bankruptcy or insolvency since—I know nothing of the prisoner's family or connexion—he told me he had a wife—he has never asked me to go over the accounts with him, and settle them—I had a suspicion about Miss Cripps about three weeks before I took the prisoner into custody—I began to suspect him, and then I examined my books, and found he had altered them, and been carrying on a systematic system of robbery—I was horror-struck, because I had treated the man more like a brother than a clerk—I then went round to the different parties, and took a copy of their receipts—I became acquainted with this account of Miss Cripps about two days before the 24th of Dec.—I went down to Miss Cripps, and took a copy of the accounts—I had occasion to be in the City on Christmas-eve, and had dis
covered other things of the prisoner, and I thought it right to arrest him—he had asked me in the morning, before I went out, if he could get away on the Monday, as he was going boxing—when I returned I brought an officer, and gave him into custody—I went before Mr. Rawlinson, the Magistrate, about this affair of Miss Cripps, on the 26th of Dec, and then I begged a remand for a week, that I might get ray evidence up—he was remanded, and at the end of that week the Magistrate asked if I had any other parties—I said, "Yes, a great many," and he said he had better remand him—I produced seven or eight of these parties, but only two of them were examined, (Mr. Devaux of Great Distaff-lane, and Miss Cripps)—the Magistrate did not tell me, when he had heard all my accusation, that it was a matter of account—he said, "Could you not arrange it?"—the Magistrate was not certain what it war—the pri
soner's wife came to see me on this business.
NOT GUILTY .
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner, on which Mr. Doane offered no evidence.)

789.
EDWARD LEWIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Nov., 1 plane, value 5s., the goods of
Ireland Thurgood.
(The prisoner being deaf and dumb, had the evidence communicated to him by signs.)
MR. CROUCH conducted the Prosecution.

ANN THURGOOD . I am the wife of William Ireland Thurgood—we live in Brick-lane, St. Luke's. On the 2nd of Nov. my husband was at work two streets off, and the prisoner came to my house, as if from my husband, to get a plane—he went outside the door, and beckoned to the street where he saw my husband, and made a motion of a plane on the side of the door—he pointed to the shop where the tools were kept—I understood by his motions that he wanted a plane—I asked him if he came from my husband, and he made signs that he had—I gave him the plane, believing he had come from my husband—he went the road towards where my husband was, but he ran up a contrary street—I ran after him, but he got out of my sight—the plane has not been found—I never saw the prisoner again till the 23rd of Jan.

COURT. Q. May you not be mistaken as to his coming from your hus
band? A. No—he went outside the street-door, and beckoned to the street.
WILLIAM IRELAND THURGOOD . I did not send the prisoner for this plane—I knew him—he never went on errands for me—I was on a scaffolding—he passed, I nodded to him and he to me.
NOT GUILTY .

790.
PATRICK COCHRANE and
WILLIAM MERCER were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of Jan., 18 cigars, value 1s., the goods of
Samuel Stephen Newland; and that Mercer had been before convicted of felony.

HARRIET NEWLAND . I am the wife of Samuel Stephen Newland, of Nas-sau-street, Commercial-road. I was in my back-shop on the 26th of Jan., and saw Mercer come in—I went in to serve him—when I got outside my room-door he went out—I went to my counter, and saw the lid off my cigars, and there was only one left—there had been from a dozen and a half to two dozen—I went to my door, and saw Mercer outside, and Cochrane stood next to the next neighbour's—I said, "You thieving vagabonds, you have got my cigars"—they made a run, and there was no person near—the first person I saw was my husband—I will swear the prisoners are the two persons I saw, and they were shuffling their hands, as if they were parting something.

JOSEPH HARROW . I live in Grenville-street, Somers-town. I was going to my sister's, and saw the two prisoners running down James-street, one after the other, and no one but them—that is the first turning past the prose
cutor's—my attention was directed to them by hearing one of them say, "Go on, go on"—I crossed and stopped them both—Mercer said, "What do you stop me for? I was crying, Stop thief"—I went to the spot where it appeared there had been a separation, and I found one cigar on the pavement.

GEORGE HAYES (police-constable K 54.) I took a lantern, and found fif
teen cigars in the middle of the road, as if they had been thrown from a hat or cap.

WILLIAM WISEMAN (police-constable K 156.) I took Mercer—on our way be said, "I only took two or three;" and in reply to an observation of Cochrane, he said, "I suppose we shall have six months"—I have seen the prisoners together before.
Cochrane. I had nothing to do with the cigars.
Mercer. I was not in her shop.
THOMAS BARTLETT (police-constable K 286.) I produce a certificate of Mercer's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person

COCHRANE—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

MERCER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.
NOT GUILTY .

792.
ANN REYNOLDS was indicted
for a like offence.
NOT GUILTY .

793.
EDWARD MAYNARD was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.

DANIEL EDDS . I am a timber-merchant. On the 18th of Jan., about half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner, who was a stranger, came and said he wanted to purchase some timber for his master—he said his mas
ter's name was Bardon, in the Mile-end-road, near Bow, and he wanted some stocks and other things for his master—I let him have forty coach-stocks, be
lieving he was employed by Mr. Bardon, or I should not have let him had them—I sent my carman with the stocks, and he could not find a Mr. Bardon.
RICHARD HENRY SAYERS . I live in Mile-end. There is no Mr. Bardon, a coachmaker, in Mile-end-road, to my knowledge, and I know most of the persons there.

CHARLES WALKER . I took the stocks, and could not find the person—I was bringing them home—I met the prisoner at the turnpike-gate—he took me down Dog-row, and unloaded them at a little wheeler's shop—that is near Mile-end-road—I have not been there since for the money.

JOHN FRENCH . I am a wheelwright. The prisoner asked my permission to leave these stocks at my shop—I said he might if it was not for long—they remained about half an hour, and then they were taken away—I know no such person as Mr. Bardon.

GEORGE HARLEY . I bought the stocks of another man, who was in com
pany pany with the prisoner, and he gave the receipt.

Prisoner. It was Mr. Bardon who sold them to this witness—Mr. Bardon and I went and looked out some goods—Mr. Edds asked his name and address, and he gave it him; "Mile-end, near Bow," and he gave me 1s. for looking out the goods.
MR. EDDS. No, I had no note or address given me.

GUILTY . * Aged 46.—
Confined One Year.

794.
JOSEPH HILL was indicted
for wliful and corrupt perjury.
NOT GUILTY .

795.
JOSEPH AUGUSTUS ARTMAN was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

796.
DIANA WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan., 1 basket, value 1d.; 5 shirts, 15s.; 4 handkerchiefs, 10s.; 2 pair of stock
ings, 2s. 6d.; 1 pair of drawers, 2s.; and 6 collars, 9s.; the goods of
John Catton, from the person of
Eliza Bright;to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

797.
SARAH MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Jan.,1 pair of boots, value 12s.; and 1 handkerchief, 3s.; the goods of
Walter Scott Barry; to which she pleaded

798.
JAMES YOUNG was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan., 2 coppers, value 1l. 13s., the goods of
William Burtt Wilton.

WILLIAM BURRT WILTON . I am a plumber, and live in High-street, Deptford. On the 23rd of Jan. my servant placed four coppers outside my window; two of them were taken—I have examined these two, and have no doubt whatever that they are mine.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know them by? A. By a chalk mark which I placed on them—here is the mark on one of them now—I was at home all day.

THOMAS COOK . About six or seven this evening I was in King-street, Deptford—I saw a man go by with two coppers on his head—he was about the size of the prisoner—he had corderoy trowsers on, a black waistcoat, and fustian sleeves to his jacket—I did not see his face.

JOHN BREENAN (police-constable R 67.) About half-past five on the 23rd of Jan. I was on duty—I saw a man resembling the prisoner with a copper on his head—I followed him down Old King-street—in coming near to Fishing Smack-alley I lost sight of him all at once—I returned and met the prosecutor, who said that two coppers were stolen from outside his shop window—about half an hour after the prisoner came out of that alley and down King-street—I took him into custody, and told him I suspected him to be the man that stole two coppers from High-street—he said it was not him—I asked his name—he said Williams, and he lived in London—I went to his house, and on Tuesday the 24th found these two coppers in the cellar under the apartment where he lived.
Cross-examined. Q. You never saw him there? A. No, the house is in Old King-street, Deptford—there was no number.
BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant K 15.) The prisoner lived in Old King-street, Deptford—a lodging-house adjoins his.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever see him in the house? A. Yes, many times—he lived in the front-room, down stairs—a person could get from the adjoining house to where he lived—I saw some footsteps from a piece of waste ground at the back, which leads from Fishing Smack-alley—there were other persons living in the house—his wife bad been confined nearly a month.

COURT. Q. He had this whole house? A. Yes—he used to let it out—no one lives in the cellar—there is a parcel of lumber in it—Fishing Smack-alley is about 100 yards from his house—there were traces from that alley to his premises, and over his fence on the top of the pig-sty.
NOT GUILTY .

799.
RICHARD TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Jan., 1 handkerchief, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Caroline Eliza Gill.

CAROLINE ELIZA GILL . I am an unfortunate girl. The prisoner came to lodge with me on Sunday night, the 8th of Jan., and left between seven and eight o'clock next morning—I missed a silk handkerchief from a chair at the foot of the bed—this is it, I am quite sure—he was quite sober—he paid me—I am sure he is the man—he was with me from half-past eleven till a quarter before eight—this handkerchief was bought and made a present to me on the New Year's-day.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You met him in the street? A.
No—I was standing at my lodging-house—I got out of bed just after he left, and missed my handkerchief—I hemmed one side of it myself.

JOHN SPARKS LOVICK . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this handkerchief—it was pawned by the prisoner, to the best of my knowledge, about eight o'clock in the morning of the 9th of Jan., for 2s.—I am positive he is the man.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

800.
HANNAH ANN ASHDOWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Jan., 2 gowns, value 4s.; 1 table-cloth, 1s. 6d.; 1 cloak, 3s.; 1 sheet, 2s.; 1 shirt, 3s.; 1 yard of flannel, 1s.; 2 coats, 4s.; 8 pinafores, 2s.; 1 petticoat, 1s.; 2 frocks, 2s.; 1 yard of holland, 1s.; and 1 handkerchief, 2s.; the goods of
William Weller; and that she had been before convicted of felony: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Transported for Seven Years.

801.
LOUISA RUSH was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Jan., 3 pairs of boots, value 1l., the goods of
Joseph Mead;
also, on the 28th of Jan., 1 gown, 4s.; 3 brooches, 12s.; 1 breast-pin, 2s. 6d.; and 1 pair of ear-rings, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
William Branch;to all which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Nine Months.

802.
JOHN OUSBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Jan., 1 piece of lead, 1s.; 1 other piece of lead, 1s.; and 9lbs. weight of lead, 2s.; the goods of
our Lady the Queen; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.

803.
ANN KELLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Jan., 4 1/2 yards of ribbon, value 1s. 8d., the goods of
John Orrick Kennard.

JOHN ABEL GROVES . I am apprentice to John Orrick Kennard, of the Broadway, Deptford. On the 19th of Jan. the prisoner came into the shop with another person, who asked for muslin—I showed her that, and then she asked for some fringe—I saw the prisoner take the ribbon from a basket on the counter, and put it under her cloak—I then acquainted my fellow ap
prentice, and told him to keep his eye on her while I went and told Mr. Kennard—I then charged her with stealing the ribbon, and asked her for it—she pulled it from under her cloak in our presence—I gave her into custody.
HENRY HITCHCOCK . I saw her take this ribbon from under her cloak, after she was charged with it.

GUILTY . Aged 56.—
Confined Three Months.

804.
WILLIAM SMART was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Oct., 1 hammer, value 2s., the goods of
William Hiskins.
WILLIAM SMART . I am in the employ of Mr. Graham, a builder. On the 15th of Oct. I missed my hammer—this is it—it has my mark upon it.
Prisoner. Q. Where did you leave it? A. On Mr. Stone's wharf.
GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) I searched the prisoner's box on another charge, and found this hammer.
Prisoner. I found it in Mr. Graham's yard—it was taken into my house, and thrown into a basket with some old tools—no one called for it.

WILLIAM HISKINS
re-examined. I left it at Mr. Stone's yard at night, and when I came back next morning it was missing from the rent of the tools—they were covered over with an apron—the prisoner was carting bricks to these premises—it is a private wharf, locked up—other persons might have had access to the wharf.
NOT GUILTY .

805.
WILLIAM SMART was again indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Jan., 56lbs. weight of hay, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
George Hall Graham; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES MOULTON . I am in the employ of Mr. George Hall Graham, a builder, at Woolwich. I watched his yard on Thursday night, the 19th of Jan.—I placed myself in the corner of the yard, and bad put some paper into a truss of hay in the yard—on that evening I missed a truss of hay from the yard—I communicated the circumstance to my master—the constable brought me some hay on the 22nd, and showed me a paper, which was what I had placed in the hay—it has my name on it.

GEORGE HARRIS . I found this paper in the manger of the stable where the prisoner's horses stand—there was a little hay in the rack—I compared it with Mr. Graham's hay, and, as far as I could judge, it corresponded.
Prisoner. I purchased the truss of hay at Mr. Sears'. Witness. He did not tell me that at the time—his stable is near Mr. Graham's.
Prisoner. There is another horse in the stable, and how that paper came there I do not know.

OBADIAH BELTON . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former con
viction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.
GUILTY .—Aged 63.

806.
WILLIAM SMART was again indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Jan., 56lbs. weight of hay, value 2s. 6d., the good of
George Hall Graham.

JAMES MOULTON . On the 22nd of Jan. I saw the prisoner take this truus of hay away, and throw it over the fence—he then took it into his stable—I got an officer, and took the truss of hay down, and found in it these two tickets, which I had put there.
JOHN WADE . I am a hay-binder. I found this truss—I believe it to be Mr. Graham's property.

GUILTY . Aged 63.—
Transported for Seven Years.

807.
JOHN SAWYER was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 3d., the goods of
Joseph Mead.

JOSEPH MEAD . I am a shoemaker, and live in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich. The prisoner was my journeyman—in consequence of information, I went and called the prisoner back from across the road, and accused him of having some of my property—he said he had not—I said I had lost a great deal—my wife came out, and said it was no use his denying it, she saw them in his pocket—he pulled these shoes out of his pocket—he had no business at all with them—they are mine.

GUILTY . * Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

808.
THOMAS PAYNE and
JAMES OSBORNE were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of Jan., 10 quires of paper, value 5s.; 1 box, 1d.; 2 purse-slides, 1s.; 2 tassels, 1s.; and 1 printed book, 1l, 5s. the goods of
Jabez Tuck; to which they pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Ten Days, and
Whipped.

809.
CHARLES SOMERVILLE was indicted
for embezzling 4l., the monies of
Samuel Franklin, his master;to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

810.
JOHN FOULKES was indicted
for embezzling the sums of 5s. 9d., 9s. 3 1/2 d., and 5s. 5d., the monies of
Ann Sirett, his mistress; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

811.
WILLIAM TAYLOR,
JOSEPH WILLEY,
JOHN RYAN , and
JOHN DONOGHUE , were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Phillip Penn, on the 23rd of Jan., at St. George the Martyr, Southwark, and stealing therein, 1 looking-glass and frame, value 2l. 2s.; 1 counterpane, 10s.; 3 spoons, 12s.; 4 shirts, 12s.; 3 pairs of stays, 10s.; 1 cloak, 15s.; 2 necklaces, 1l. 2s.; 5 petticoats, 5s.; 2 sheets, 16s.; 3 frocks, 8s.; 3 bed-gowns, 3s.; 3 shifts, 4s.; 1 yard of flannel, 1s.; 2 pairs of drawers, 1s.; 3 aprons, 1s.; 3 pinafores, 1s.; 6 handkerchiefs, 2s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 2s. 6d.; 3 caps, 1s.; 1 towel, 3d.; 1 waistcoat, 6d.; and 1 pair of stockings, 9d.; his goods.

WILLIAM KELLY . I am a hatter. On Monday erening, the 23rd of Jan., I went to Mr. Penn's—he requested me to attend to the parties in his tap-room—I was at the bar, turned round, and saw Taylor going out with a keg under his arm—I took it from him, and gave it to Penn—about a quarter of an hour after I went into the tap-room, with a pot of beer, to a person named Sculley, the prisoner Willey and a man named Vickery were there—Willey called me on one side to the fire—he was in company with one of the sweeps—(Taylor and Ryan are sweeps)—I cannot say which, and a man named Vickery—he said they were going up stairs to do some business, and if I saw any thing I would not say any thing—it was spoken to frighten me, and I seemed to take no notice, being fearful of the manner the words were expressed to me—I was fearful to tell them what my determination was—I told them it was nothing to do with me what business they were going to do up stairs, and as soon as I had an opportunity I went out from the tap-room to the bar—Mr. Penn being engaged at the bar with parties, I went into the kitchen immediately, and there told the servant-girl.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Where do you carry on business as a hatter? A. Nowhere at present—I was apprentice and journeyman to Mr. Anderson, in Edward-street—I get my living by my wife's work—I have not been in the police force within these eighteen months—I resigned—I was fearful of getting dismissed—I got quarrelling and fighting—I should have had an order to quit—I had been in the force from February till August—the conversation between me and Willey took place in the tap-room—I cannot exactly say whether there were twelve persons there—I do not suppose there were fifteen—I should say about ten—there might be more or less—I did not tell any one of those ten people what Willey said to me—I was at tht Duke's Head the following morning—I did not see Willey there—I did not know of his being there—I did not see him there the following evening, nor till I saw him at Union-hall—I did not know of his being there.

PHILIP PENN . I am a publican, and keep the Duke's Head, Mint-street, Borough, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark. On Mon
day, the 23rd of Jan., about seven o'clock in the evening, the servant came up to me—I saw her go up stairs—she came down, and fainted away—I went up and saw the bed-room stripped, the bed-clothes stripped off the bed, and

the window open—I came down into my own bar again—soon afterwards some boys came in—I asked a man named Vickery to come up stairs, and bring a light, which he did—I went into the bed-room, got out of the window on to the leads, and saw the looking-glass there—Vickery and I came down, and sent for a policeman—I was sent for up Harrow-street, where the things were found—as I was going up the street, Donoghue came up to me and said, "Halloa, what is the matter?" or something similar to that; "I can tell you where the things are; what will you stand?"—I do not recollect saying any
thing to him before that, to my knowledge—I cannot say who spoke first—I had not spoken to him before he said, "Halloa, what is the matter?"—I was running up the street—I told him I had been robbed, and he said, "I think I can tell you where the things are that were taken out of the house".—(I did not say what I had been robbed of)—I told him I would give him a glass of anything to drink if he did—we went up to the van, at the top of the street—I got up, looked into the van, and saw the things exactly in the place he said they were—I saw linen sheets and shirts there that I had just missed from the bed-room—I told the man with the van to take care of the things, and bring them back to my house—I went back with Donoghue, and he had a glass of spirits—one of the boys that came in said Donoghue was throwing the clothes up into the van, and I gave him into custody on that charge.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you known Donoghue? A. Yes, twelve months—I should say he was very fresh indeed—what I gave him did not hurt him—I will not swear what he took—it was seven o'clock or half-past—it was dark out of doors.

GRACE PENN . I am the prosecutor's wife. I left home at a quarter-past three o'clock—I left the bed-room door and the door on the stairs locked, and my keys hanging in the bar—when I came home, about twenty minutes or half-past seven o'clock, the house was in confusion—I found the staircase
door unlocked, not broken open, and the bed-room door unlocked too—it had not been forced—the property was all brought down into the kitchen—there was dirty and clean linen, a quantity of children's things, some ribbon, and other things in the looking-glass drawer—I believe the value altogether is 9l. or 10l.—when I left the bed-room the sash-window was fastened by a bolt in the centre frame, and a brass screw in the end—it was secured tight—there was no pane broken or cracked—when I came back the whole of a pane was nearly out—a person could get at the screw in that way—the bolt was undone, and the screw drawn out—that was the way the persons got in—the house is in the parish of St. George the Martyr.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know the parish? A. We pay rates, and that name is on all the papers—my husband, myself, three children, (the eldest nine years old,) and the servant, all live in the house—the key in the bar was exposed, but no one could reach it—the maid-servant does not come into the bar without her master tells her—I cannot say whether my husband was away from the bar—ours is a back bed-room—there is a gate half-way up the stairs—that was locked, and the bed-room too—the keys of both hung together—the other bed-room had not been disturbed—the key of that hung in the bar with the others.

SAMUEL WARD . I am fifteen years old, and am out of work; I was in work, about twelve months ago, at Mr. Bartlett's a grocer, in Cannon-street; my mother supports me. On the 23rd of January, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner Ryan chuck the things over the railing—another man caught them, and went towards a van with them, which was at the other end of the street—Ryan was on the top of Mr. Penn's leads,

throwing white things like linen over the railing—I went and told Mr. Penn—he went up stairs—I went out—I saw nothing more—I do not know who the other man was, his hack was towards me—I left Mr. Bartlett's service because I stopped away two or three days, and he discharged me.

WILLIAM CARLTON . I am fourteen years old, I work for my father as a bricklayer. I was standing on the opposite side of the way, and saw Ryan throw the things over the railing—I was not with Ward—I saw a man catch them, but did not see his face—I saw Ryan's face quite well by the blase of a farrier's forge—I went in and told Mr. Penn—I stood by the bar while he went up stairs—Ward came in directly after me—the two sweeps, Taylor and Ryan, came from the backyard through the passage—I knew them by sight—I am sure it was them—I did not know their names before they went out—they had nothing with them.

Taylor. Q. Where was you when I came from the backyard? A. Stand
ing by the bar, I could not see which of you came in out of the yard first—you were together, and went out at the front-door—I remained in the house.

WALTER WILLIAMS . I am fifteen years old, and am a pearl-worker. I saw Ryan chuck the things into the van—I have seen him before, going into Penn's house, and know him by sight—he was at the other end of the street by the van, about two minutes' walk from Penn's, not out of sight of the house—he was throwing white things, like linen, into the van—saw Do-noghue by the side of him—I knew him before, he lived opposite Penn's—I live at the bottom of the street—I went and called my father, he came out with a light, and looked in the van and found the things in it—he sent my mother up to Penn's house to tell him—there was nobody there when my father came out with a light, they had gone away—I did not see Donoghue handle any thing, nor speak to the other one—he was close to the van.
Cross-examined. Q. What time was it? A. Past seven o'clock, it was dark—Donoghue did nothing at all—I did not speak to him, he was very tipsy.

COURT. Q. Whose van was it? A. My father's—there was no horse to it—I was examined three times before the Magistrate, about the van every time—the van was standing where it usually does when it is not wanted, by our door—my father has not a horse of his own, be hires one—the van is used for moving goods.

JOHN WILLIAMS . I am the father of last witness, I live within a few doors of Mr. Penn. My son gave me information—I went out with a light, saw the linen and things in the van—I sent my wife to tell Penn—he came to the van—I tied the things up, and carried them home for him, into a place behind the bar.

THOMAS CHURCH . I am a policeman. At ten minutes after nine o'clock, from information I received, I went to Penn's house—I saw the prisoner Taylor with two women, standing near the back-door which leads into the yard—Taylor immediately went into the yard, leaving the women—I followed him, and found him in the water-closet—I could not see him, he being a sweep, and it being dark—I called out, "I want you"—he came out, and I took him to the station—I returned immediately afterwards to Penn's house, searched the water-closet which I took him from, and found this knife thrown down the water-closet, and on the blade of it are several pieces of putty—I can almost swear it was putty, from the state it was then in—I afterwards went up stairs into the room, and fitted the knife to some marks in the middle pane of a window, and the point of the knife corresponded exactly with the marks where the pane had been broken, by which means the robbery had been effected—the putty had been scraped out on one side, and at the bottom there was two marks on the edge of the frame—I saw marks of soot on the

bed-curtains and on the mattress—I do not know any of the prisoners—Taylor was black, like a sweep—I saw marks of white on his knees, shoulders, and arms, at the station, such as a person would have by climbing up a white wall—there were also marks of black on the inside of Penns wall, such as sweep would make by getting up—marks of a person's toes—the wall is about twelve feet high—there is a urinal in the yard, a water-closet door, and a wall above, then the leads, so that it is like a pair of stairs—he could get on the leads very easily, and on that lead the window opens.

Cross-examined. Q. Whose feet would you swear made the marks? A. I cannot swear—they appeared to be marks of toes—I do not swear they were—I almost swear the marks on the knife were marks of putty—it is a common sort of a knife—I fitted it in the wood where the putty was scraped away, and it corresponded—no doubt any common knife would produce the same mark.

AMBROSE MUGFORD . I am a policeman. I was at the station, about half-past seven o'clock, when a boy came—I was ordered to go up to Mr. Penn's house—I went, and Penn gave Ryan into custody—I took him to the station—I was going back to the house, and saw a brother constable with Donoghne, and assisted in taking him to the station—I went to Perm's house, and brought the goods to the station in a bundle—I have seen Taylor and Ryan before—Taylor is a sweep, and is generally black—I never saw Ryan with a black face before.

Taylor's Defence. His statement was quite different at Union-hall; they convicted one another there; one of the boys said he saw Ryan throw things over the wall, and a man underneath in a brown coat caught them, and ran up to the van; one of the other boys said he saw Ryan throw them into the van himself; he did not say so at Union-hall; one swore it was a man in a brown coat, and the other said it was Ryan; I never had the knife in my possession; I had been in the house an hour and a half; I went backwards, and had not been there five minutes before the policeman came.

TAYLOR—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

RYAN—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

WILLEY—
NOT GUILTY .

DONOGHUE—
NOT GUILTY .

812.
WILLIAM TAYLOR was again indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Jan., 1 keg, value 15s.; and 1 quart of peppermint, 2s. 8d.; the goods of
Philip Penn.

PHILIP PENN . I keep the Duke's Head. On the 23rd of Jan., about half-past six o'clock, I was in the bar—Kelly brought me a keg—I said, "Who took it?"—he said, "Taylor"—I took it from him, and put it behind the bar—there was about a pint of peppermint in it—it was mine—I saw it that evening on a corner of a shelf inside the bar—it could be reached from outside the bar, from the staircase—it had a brass tap to it—I went for a policeman, but could not find one.

Prisoner. Q. What did Kelly say to you? A. He at first told me he picked it up off the floor—he then said he took it from underneath your arm—I never saw you till afterwards—I did not go into the tap-room—the other robbery was committed about ten minutes after, and then I hardly knew what I was about—I was busy at the time—there were other people outside the bar, but not inside.

WILLIAM KELLY . I was waiting at the bar for a pot of beer, which Mr. Penn was going to draw for a customer—I saw Taylor going in the direction of the door with the keg under his arm—I immediately took it from him, and gave it to Mr. Penn, telling him who I took it from—he was not drunk.

Prisoner. Q. What did you say to Mr. Penn when you took it from me? A. That I took it from under your arm—I placed it on the ground after I took it from you, and took it up again—Mr. Penn could not leave the bar to give you in charge—I did not say at Union-hall that the reason I did not say any
thing was because I did not like to have a piece of work—that was about the other thing.

JURY. Q. Did he make any resistance when you attempted to take the keg from him? A. No, he went away from the bar as soon as I took the keg from him—he might have gone into the tap-room—I saw him again that evening frequently in and out of the tap-room till he was taken—I did not say any more about the keg—I did not molest him—I had nothing to do with it—he did not have any thing to drink that I know of—I cannot say how long he stopped in the tap-room—I received nothing for my services that night, I merely did it out of kindness, Mr. Penn requesting me previous to the robbery being committed—he had a previous knowledge of me—when I took the keg from the prisoner he was in the house going towards the street-door—it was about a quarter of an hoar before the other robbery took place.
THOMAS CHURCHILL . I am a policeman. I produce the keg.
MR. PENN re-examined. This it my keg.

Prisoner's Defence. It is all false what Kelly says; I never went out till I heard the robbery was committed, and then I went to see what was the matter; the keg was taken before. I got the white on my clothes at the station by sitting against the boards there.

THOMAS CHURCHILL
re-examined. The wall of the police-cell is not white—there is part white considerably above where the prisoner's knees could possibly get—there is iron four or five feet high—I noticed the white when I took him at Penn's house.
GUILTY .

813.
THOMAS MAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Jan., at Camberwell, 9 forks, value 5l.; 13 spoons, 5l.; and 1 knife, 8s.; the goods of
George Glenny Anderson, in his dwelling-house.

RACHEL HART . I am servant to Mr. George Glenny Anderson, of Dul
wich-common, in the parish of Camberwell. On the 80th of Jan. I went out of the kitchen into the pantry, and while there heard a noise of the plate in the kitchen—I had left some silver forks and spoons on the dresser, amount
ing to between 8l. and 9l.—I went into the kitchen, and saw the prisoner with the plate in both his hands, all out of the basket—I pushed him back to the dresser, and he dropped part of it in the basket, and part out—I seized hold of him, and asked what brought him there—he said he wag doing nothing—he said after that he was begging—I gave him into custody.

Prisoner. I went into the kitchen to look for some bread; I happened to knock against the tray, the servant came in, and said I had taken the plate; I had not touched it. Witness. He had moved all the plate from where I had left it—I had not known him before—the boy had just gone out for a can of water, and left the door open—the plate was in a little, deep black tray, which I used to keep the knives in—I had put it there to wash it—I did not knock any of it down on the ground—I am positive he had it in his hand.

CHARLES SIMMONS . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—the prosecutor's house is in the parish of Camberwell—we have only got one spoon here, the lady would not let her bring the rest—I saw it at the time.

GUILTY . * Aged 15.—
Transported for Ten Years.

814.
FREDERICK CHARLES BURNHAM BLACKWELL, alias Frederick Burnham Blackwell , was indicted
for feloniously forging and utter
ing, at Camberwell, on the 30th of Dec., a certain deed, purporting to be an indenture, made in the year 1840, between one
Richard Constable,
Eliza
beth Hollis Constable, and
Joseph Stanley, with intent to defraud the said
Elizabeth Hollis Constable.—4 other COUNTS, varying the manner of laying the charge.—2 other COUNTS, stating his intent to be to defraud
Eliza Watts.—2 other COUNTS, stating his intent to be to defraud
Richard Con
stable.—6 other COUNTS, for forging and uttering a certain written instru
ment, purporting to be a deed, with the like intents.

RICHARD BIRCH . I am a solicitor; until lately I was in partnership with Mr. Sutcliffe; we carried on business in New Bridge-street, Black friars—we were professionally concerned for the late Richard Constable—I believe our engagements with him commenced in May, 1838; he was at that time residing in Manor-street, Kennington—he had a life-interest in a place called Mount Pleasant, at Lewisham, at that time—I prepared his will—I cannot say when—he died on the 31st of December, 1840—this is the probate of the will—(looking at it)—after the execution of his will I prepared a deed of settlement, by way of conveyance of his property; that must have been about Feb., 1839—I prepared the deeds on behalf of Mr. Constable—these are the deeds—I pre
pared this deed of the 1st Feb., 1839, and here is another of the 4th and 5th—they were prepared at the same time—I attended the execution of them—all these instruments assume to dispose of his real property—Mr. Constable was introduced to us as a client, by a Mr. Joseph Stanley—I do not know when Stanley died—from time to time, during Mr. Constable's lifetime, Stanley saw me on the part of Mr. Constable, about his affairs—Mr. Constable was very old and infirm—I have no doubt that Stanley came to me in July, 1840—he came, I think, in Aug., 1840, and gave me instructions about preparing a deed—I prepared the deed, in pursuance of written directions, which I believed were given by Mr. Constable—I had a letter, which I believed, at that time, to have been written by Mr. Constable—that letter was handed, with all Mr. Constable's other papers, to Messrs. Hale, Boys, and Austen, who succeeded us in the business—I am not attesting witness to all these instruments, only to these two of the 1st of Feb., and 4th and 5th of Feb.—I think I am acquainted with the handwriting of Mr. Constable—I have seen him write, and have bad frequent letters from him—I also attested his will in January, 1839, and a mortgage-deed, in 1838, the transfer of a mortgage—this is the letter which Stanley brought to me in August, as from Mr. Constable (marked A)—in consequence of that letter I prepared the draft of a deed—Stanley brought me back the draft—it remained in my office till Dec.—I got it engrossed by Stanley's direction—this is the deed—(looking at the deed charged to be forged)—it was engrossed on the 30th of Dec., 1840, and handed to Stanley on the 31st—I am quite sure of that—I cannot form any idea as to what time of the day Stanley had the deed from us—it was the last day in the year, and we closed our office rather earlier than usual that evening, but I cannot remember the time—our office opened at ten, or a quarter to ten o'clock, and closed, I should think, at four—at the time it was given to Stanley, it was not exe
cuted by any body—it had just come from the stationer's—I cannot re
member how soon I saw the deed again—it must have been a few days—it was brought to me by Stanley, and I rather think Stanley signed the deed in my presence, but I am not sure—when he brought it, it was executed as

it now appears, signed by Mr. Constable, and attested, as to the signature of Mr. Constable and his daughter, by the prisoner—I did not see that done, it was brought back in that state—I cannot be certain whether Stanley signed it in my presence—I remember baring some conversation with Stanley about the deed—I think he signed it—he was a party to the deed—his signature is to the deed as a party to it—I know the prisoner—I do not think I saw him at all during Mr. Constable's lifetime—after his death, and the deposit of that deed with us by Stanley, I saw the prisoner at my office some few times—he came, relative to the Lewisham affair, and the affairs of Mr. Constable generally—he came from Stanley—he assigned Stanley's illness as a reason for his coming instead of Stanley—he told me where Stanley lived, when I was desired to go down and see Stanley at Mount Pleasant—I went down, and found Stanley there—that must have been in the summer of 1841—it must have been shortly before his death, which was in August, 1841—I remember the prisoner calling at my office while Stanley was ill, when Miss Constable was there, and I introduced them—I told Miss Constable that the prisoner was a nephew of Stanley's, and she said in his pre
sence she was glad at seeing him for the first time—after introducing them, I left them to talk by themselves—Miss Constable was very desirous of knowing the state of Stanley's health—before that I bad not looked at the deed with any atten
tion—I was not aware that the prisoner purported to be the attesting witness to Miss Constable's signature to the deed—on that occasion Miss Constable expressed herself to him as a person she had not seen before—something was said about Stanley's being ill—Miss Constable desired to know where he was to be found, and to be informed of his state of health from time to time—the pri
soner did not tell her where he was to be found—he did not give hit address, but promised to inform her from time to time of his health—I do not know what he said about the address, but it was concealed both from me and her—the forged deed remained at my office until Stanley's death—after Stanley's death, the prisoner called on me, and produced a paper, which he described as being Stanley's will—after I had read the will, and discovered that Stanley had been devising this gentleman's estate to the prisoner, I explained to the pri
soner, or to Mr. Jones, a professional gentleman, who was with him, that Stanley had no interest in the estate beyond the payment of a debt that was secured by this deed—at that time I considered this deed to be a genuine document—he produced the original will at the time—it had not been proved—I still re
tained the deed in my possession—I had a lien on it for costs incurred in the preparation—application was made to a Judge for an order to compel me to deliver it up, which was refused—my costs were something above 100l. I ultimately delivered up the deed without an order—I cannot give the date when the deed left my possession—it was delivered up on the payment of my costs due from Mr. Constable.

Q. The application about that deed to the Judge occurred on the 1st of Dec., 1841? A. Then the deed must have gone out of our hands a few days after that—I was not present when the deed was handed to the party—I had examined it before it left my office, to see how it was executed—at the time I parted with it to the prisoner it had the same attestation and execution to it as it has now—it purported to be signed by Richard Constable, Elizabeth Hollis Constable, and Joseph Stanley—at the time I introduced the prisoner to Miss Constable I had paid no attention to the mode in which the deed was attested.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How long before you received instructions to prepare the deed had you acted as attorney for Richard Con
stable? A. We acted for him from May, 1838—his business was conducted principally through the medium of Stanley—I have seen Mr. Constable—I

dare say I also received notes from him upon the subject of which I afterwards saw him—Miss Constable was living with her father at that time—I think he always wrote his own letters—I do not know of Miss Constable's sometimes being his amanuensis—I saw her frequently at the house in the course of my communications with her fathers, and he used to come on the subject of her father's affairs as well as Stanley—those visits of hers did not continue up to within a short time of Mr. Constable's death—I should say I saw nothing of her from Trinity Term, 1840, until her father's death-there was then a bill of foreclosure in Chancery with respect to the mortgage—this deed purports to be an arrangement for paying off the demands on Mr. Constable, and also paying off the mortgage—if that had been carried out, it would no doubt have relieved him from his embarrassments—it would depend, of course, on the value of the property, supposing it realised the amount, he would have the surplus, if any—I bad not been consulted by Mr. Constable himself as to the best means of proceeding to get out of his difficulties—the occasions on which I saw him were on business—Stanley lived in the house with him part of the time when I was doing business with him.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you mean at Kennington or in West-square? A. I do not know of his living at Kennington—he lived at Mount Pleasant with him.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. And Miss Constable too? A. Yes—the last time I saw Mr. Constable must have been in the early part of 1840—I transacted his business myself-I drew the draft of this deed myself—it was settled by a conveyancer—I think the draft was ready to be perused in Aug., 1840—I did not go down to Lewis ham with it—I gave it to Stanley—I cannot say how long he kept it—I know the business stood over till Dec.—at that time the proceedings in Chancery could not go on-I declined patting in the an
swer—the cause stood still for that time—I have looked at all these signa
tures to the deed—I think this one of Stanley's I saw him write—I will not be sure—I cannot say how long it was after the 31st of Dec, 1840, that I saw the prisoner—I think the first time I saw him was in consequence of his having made a bill of exchange payable and lodging some money with us—I think it must have been some months after Mr. Con
