stable's death-the deed has blanks in it—I was applied to by Stanley to perfect this deed immediately after I got it, after it was returned executed—I have never been applied to by anybody else to fill up the blanks—I told Stanley we could not supply these blanks unless we had the authority of Miss Constable-I got that authority—this paper (marked B) purports to be dated Feb., 1841—at that time I had the deed in my possession—I saw Miss Constable after this letter was delivered, not repeatedly—I saw her very few times after receiving that letter, two or three times—I think I must have seen her in the summer of 1841, but I will not swear that—the blanks have not been filled up—I did not tell her I would not fill up the blanks—I never spoke to her at all on the subject of that letter—I did not ask Stanley to get her authority to fill up the blanks—I refused to do it-after this letter purporting to be Miss Constable's authority came, I took advice as to the propriety of stamping the deed and filling up the blanks, and found it would be injudicious-it was in consequence of that advice that I did not do so—here is a sum of 53l. 16s. 8d. referred to in this letter—there had been a sum of about 50l. paid, which had been borrowed of my partner, not of the firm—that was paid by Stanley on the 24th of Dec, 1840—perhaps there might be interest on it-Stanley had borrowed 60l. of Mr. Sutcliffe, and deposited the deeds of the Lewisham estate—he borrowed it as Mr. Constable's agent, as he assumed—the 53l. was paid to my partner—I did not make the slightest reference to this letter when I saw Miss Constable-I did not expect there was any thing

to he said about the deed—I had no suspicion—I never accounted to Miss Constable for not filling up the blanks after receiving this letter—I should have mentioned it if I had been asked about it, but I never was—in my in
terviews with Miss Constable, no reference was made to the deed or the let
ter—her attention was never called to such a letter purporting to come from her.

Q. Then were you never applied to again to fill up the blanks? A. I think Stanley, after the receipt of that letter, mentioned the subject, and there the matter dropped, as far as I was concerned—when the prisoner was intro
duced to Miss Constable I think he was there on business of Mr. Constable's—the prisoner and Miss Constable never met at my office but that once to my knowledge—I think I never saw them together after that—I think the deed and the papers were delivered up without a Judge's order—we had retained them for our bill against Mr. Constable—when that was paid we delivered them up—the bill was paid to our clerk, who is here—at the time I received the deed back from Stanley, apparently executed, I believed it to be genuine—I made an affidavit, in which I stated die time the deed came out of my pos
session—that affidavit was read to Mr. Constable's medical attendant—that must have been five or six weeks after they paid the bill—that was when I first questioned the validity of the deed, in consequence of what the medical man said to me—the last payment was 41l. odd—that was some time after the 1st of Dec., 1841—I do not believe I ever applied to the prisoner for payment of our account—I did not apply to anybody—Hale and Co. had applied to us for the bill—they paid the bill that they might get the papers out of our hands—the 4l. odd was the first bill that was paid, and the other bill for 16l. was for business done for Mr. Constable—I did not endeavour to raise a loan on the deed while it was in my possession—I entered into negociation for a loan, on the old title, in Trinity Term, 1840, never after that—that money was to be raised for the purpose of paying off the mortgage—I was not then in possession of Mr. Constable's deeds—there were no deeds of Mr. Constable's in our possession, except a deed left as a deposit for 41l.—we wanted to get money to pay off the incumbrances on Mr. Constable's estate—we endeavoured to do that—I do not think I saw Mr. Constable on that subject, nor Miss Constable—all that took place was with Stanley—I do not remember ever seeing Miss Constable at any time when there was a question about getting money to pay off her father's incumbrances—I do not think she ever evinced any wish of that kind—I believe all the conversation was with Stanley. Q. What was the object of your seeing her at all? A. When she came, she came for advice on particular points, in reference to giving a notice to quit, and those sort of things—I rather think I did though, try to get money after Dec. 1840—if yoa will give me the bill, I can tell—this is my bill against Stanley—oh, yes, I remember I saw Mr. Vigors, of Chancery-lane, on the 23rd of Feb. 1841—that was soon after the deed came into my possession—I saw Mr. Vigors for the purpose of raising money to pay off all the incumbrances—I saw Stanley on that subject, but not Miss Constable—I did not succeed in raising the loan—I should say this was not one of the deeds upon which it was to be raised—it was supposed Miss Constable was in a situation to give a mortgage on the freehold estates, in concurrence with Stanley—it must have been on that deed, if Stanley had any thing to do with it—it was not carried into execution, and we were not successful in raising the money—there was another attempt made, I see, on the 22nd of March—that must have been after I got this letter, authorising me to fill up the blanks.

Q. Did not you attempt to raise money on this deed? A. The deed itself was not mentioned—we considered we could give a good mortgage on the estate, with the concurrence of Stanley and Miss Constable—Aldridge, the

mortgagee, was to be paid off—we should have indorsed something on the deed in discharge of our debt—I believe this letter (marked C) to be Mr. Constable's handwriting—the signature to this (D) is very unlike his—I never remember seeing this letter before—I really cannot say; I have a doubt about it, or else I should say at once—I have seen Miss Constable write—it is not like hers—I think it is not hers—I should say this was (E)—allow me to look at the one I have a doubt about (again looking at D)—I now think that is Mr. Constable's—I believe these are his (F and G).

Q. Did you know of Stanley's being engaged to Miss Constable? A. I never knew it from her—I never conversed with her on the subject—I knew of the fact is another way—I believed it to be a fact—I did know of it as a fact—I understood they were engaged to be married.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. who from? A. From the gentleman who introduced Mr. Stanley to me.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Was that while Mr. Constable was alive? A. Yes—I never talked to Mr. Constable about it—I cannot give the date when I last saw Mr. Constable—it must have been some time prior to Trinity Term, 1840—I dare say I looked carefully at the deed when it was delivered back to me—I cannot remember—I dare say I examined it to see that it was properly done—I cannot recollect whether I looked at the attestation, but I have no doubt I did.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. During the time you were negociating for the purpose of raising money on the title to Mr. Constable's estate, had you any reason to believe that there was any question as to the validity of this deed? A. Oh no, Miss Constable never called my attention to the letter of authority or to the deed—she never spoke to me on the subject.

THOMAS JOHN COWARD . In 1841 I was clerk to Messrs. Suteliffe and Birch. I knew the late Joseph Stanley very well—at the latter part of 1841 some proceedings were taken by Hale, Boys, and Austen, of Ely-place, to obtain pos
session of some papers in our possession—on the evening of the lstof Dec. 1841 I saw the prisoner and a clerk of Hale, Boys, and Austen, at our office, and a third person, came, whom I believe to be Mr. Newhall—Hale and Co.'s clerk said he came for the deed which we had in our possession, and to pay us the costs—the prisoner was close to him, and in hearing, the whole time—he was all the time in the same office—the clerk said the application was made on be
half of the executors of the late Joseph Stanley—I am sure the prisoner was by at that time—the clerk paid me the costs, which amounted to 168l. 15s., and the deed was given up—it was handed over to Messrs. Hale's clerk, in the prisoner's presence—this is the deed—(looking at it.)

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Was that the only instrument you banded over? A. Yes, on that evening—I should think I was half an hour before I handed it over—I was not in conversation with Messrs. Hales' clerk for some time in the prisoner's absence—I will not swear that the prisoner was not absent for a minute, but he was not absent for some time—I do not think he was absent for a minute; he was not absent for half an hour certainly.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. By whose directions did you deliver that deed to Messrs. Hales' clerk? A. By Mr. Birch's directions—he was in an inner office at the time—the prisoner was in the office all the time, and joined in the conversation, not with Mr. Birch—I dare say he said something about the deed, but I do not know precisely—at the time the clerk said he came from the executors of Mr. Stanley, I knew that the prisoner was one of those executors—I had seen him there before—he had not been on the subject of this deed that I know of, but on the subject of the property to which the deed referred.

WILLIAM JOHN MARTIN . I am clerk to Messrs. Hale, Boys, and Austen. I am subscribing witness to this agreement—I saw it executed—(This agree
ment not being stamped was not read.)

JOSEPH FRY HEAKES . I am clerk to Mr. Kirk, of Symons-inn—he is attorney for this prosecution—I produce an examined copy of an answer in Chancery in the cause of Aldridge and Blackwell—I examined it with the original in the office.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is a person named Fluker a fellow-clerk of yours? A. Yes. THOMAS HILL. I am a draper, and live in Southampton-street, Camber-well—I know the prisoner—he was living with me as shopman in 1840—I know his handwriting—I have seen it many times—the signature "F. C. B. Black well" to the attestation of this deed is his writing; also the words "by the within-named Richard Constable and Elizabeth Hollis Constable" I should say are his, (attestation read) "Signed, sealed, and delivered by the within-named Richard Constable and Elizabeth Hollis Constable, in the presence of F. C. B. Blaekwell and Lavinia Blackwell."

JOHN CHARLES WEAVER LEVER , M. D. I reside in Bridgehouse-place, Southwark. I was acquainted with the late Mr. Richard Constable—I attended him professionally up to the time of his death—he died the last day of 1840—at that time he lived in West-square, Southwark—I also knew Joseph Stanley—on the eve of Mr. Constable's death Stanley came to my house to fetch me to see Mr. Constable; in consequence of what he said, I accompanied him back to Mr. Constable's house—we got to Mr. Con
stable's house a few moments after the clock struck seven—the clock was striking seven as we entered West-square—when I got into the house Mr. Constable was just dead—I had seen him on the previous day and on that morning alive, I should think between eleven and twelve o'clock in the forenoon—I cannot exactly state the time—he was then dying—he was decidedly not capable of retaining a pen in his hand—he was not sensible.
COURT. Q. Was he so far in a dying state as not to be likely to recover his senses? A. Certainly he was not likely to recover them—I considered him a dying man from the 28th or 29th of the month.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What state was be in on the night of the 30th? A. Unable to answer questions put to him—I am speaking within bounds when I say that for thirty-six hours before his death he was incapable of answering a question—it was both a physical and mental incapacity—he had inflamma
tion of the lungs, and the brain was affected as well—there was no defect of voice—he could speak before his death, but he was more or less delirious from the 24th of December—for twenty-four hours before hit death he de
cidedly could not have written his name, or retain a pen in his hand—I know his handwriting—I have often seen him sign his name—the signature to this deed is certainly not his handwriting—I was the attesting witness to one will which he executed, not the will the probate of which has been produced—I afterwards heard of Stanley's death—Mr. Birch told me of it—in consequence of something which I heard I afterwards called at the office of Hale, Boys, and Austen, and had tome conversation with somebody there.

COURT. Q. Was there any occasion on which you heard Mr. Birch read an affidavit, as it was called? A. He read extracts from an affidavit on one occasion in my presence, upon which I called Mr. Birch's attention to the state of Mr. Constable.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long altogether had you attended Mr. Constable previous to his death? A. When he was ill, for

five or six years previously—he was, I believe, ninety years of age—I have received letters from him; I received one within six months of his death, in his own handwriting—I do not know his daughter's handwriting—I never received any letters from her—I have known her the same time as I had known her father—she lived with him, I believe, the whole time—I have at
tended her on several occasions when she was living with her father—she was in the room with him when I saw him on the morning of the 31st of Dec., the whole time—I am sure of that—I cannot state whether I found her there when I went in the morning—I do not recollect her coming into the room—I know she was there, because I remember telling her that her father would not live, most likely, twenty-four or forty-eight hours—I can undertake to swear that I told her that on the morning of the 31st of Dec.—that was in Mr. Consta
able's room, I am certain of that—I found her in Mr. Constable's room when I got there in the morning—she remained there the whole time I was there—I remained there, perhaps, a quarter of an hour that evening—I know Mr. Con
stable's handwriting perfectly well—this letter (marked A) is very much like his writing—I cannot swear that it is or is not his; I should say it was not his—one part of the signature is very much like it, and the other part is not—the "Richard" is very much like his, the remaining part of the last word is unlike his—I certainly do not believe that to be his handwriting—let me look at it again—I have not read the letter—the whole of the word "Con
stable's I believe not to be his handwriting—I believe the "Richard" to be very much like his—I do not believe this (C) to be his handwriting, nor this (D)—I believe this (E) to be his, and these (H and F)—I do not believe this (G) to be his.

Q. When had you any suspicion of anything wrong?—was it when you beard something read out in your presence by Mr. Birch? A. Yes; my suspicions were first attracted by that circumstance—I cannot fix the date of that—it was after the 5th of Nov.; I think the beginning of Dec.; I cannot say exactly—it was on a Friday, either the first or second Friday in Dec.—I had a bill against the executors of Mr. Constable for my attendance on him, I think it was about 30l.—that has not been paid—I have requested pay
ment of it—I have requested payment from Miss Constable herself, as execu
trix under the will—I first requested payment from her a few weeks, perhaps a month, after her father's death, when she was getting together the bills that were due—I afterwards applied to the prisoner, before 1 knew of the exist
ence of this deed—it was about the 6th or 7th of Nov. that I first applied to him—I have seen him once or twice—I have applied to him verbally and otherwise, perhaps, three or four times—I wrote to him after I heard the affidavit read of the existence of this deed.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you make any application to him after you knew of this deed, except in writing? A. No.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you and he any personal dispute about it? A. None at all—when I applied to him in writing I did not get my money, or any answer—it was not then for the first time that I mentioned my sus
picions to anybody—I had mentioned them to Mr. Hale before—that was after my endeavours to get the bill from the prisoner—when I first applied to the prisoner I did not know of the existence of this deed—I knew of Stan
ley's death, and had read of Stanley's will, in Doctors' Commons, leaving his property to his nephews and nieces—I had no dispute with the prisoner about a picture—I requested him to give me one, which Mr. Constable had presented me with in his lifetime.

Q. What made you apply to the prisoner for Mr. Constable's picture? A. Because I understood from Mr. Birch that he had come into possession of the property—he promised to send me the picture—he did not do so—I have
since got it from Miss Constable, perhaps two months ago—I first saw Miss Constable after writing to the prisoner last summer—this is the letter I wrote to the prisoner—(produced.)

Q. Had you at that time the slightest intention of saying one single word about your suspicions, if you had been paid the amount of your bill? A. Certainly I had—I should not have moved in the case, paid or not, unless I bad been subpœnaed or summoned—I cannot swear that I did not mention the case to anybody after writing this letter—I may have mentioned the case, but I should not have forwarded the case unless subpœnaed or summoned—I should not have come forward in the matter at all—I was acquainted with Miss Constable as long as I knew her father—I certainly thought that a deed of this kind would materially affect her interests—I certainly did not mean to do anything about it unless summoned or subpœnaed—I should have kept perfectly quiet up to the present moment, unless I had been summoned or subpœnaed—I did not, on the prisoner not paying my bill, go and make a communication without being summoned or subpœnaed—I might have mentioned it—I cannot tell to whom—I went to Mr. Hale before I wrote that letter—I did not make any communication after Writing that letter, till one of Mr. Kirk's clerks called on me for my information—I cannot tell how he came to do that—I think I had not made any communica
tions previously—I was first summoned to Union-hall—I cannot say whether I had made any communication to anybody previous to that—I might have talked of it, but it must have been in the course of conversation, not to forward any criminal proceedings—my bill has not been paid—Miss Constable has not promised to pay it—I have not applied to her for pay
ment since this affair—I did not apply to her for the picture—she left it at a house for me—I have had no communication about the payment of my bill since, with anybody—I made no further application after receiving no answer to my letter—I let the thing rest until I was summoned to Union-hall.

MR. CLARAKSON. Q. How long have you been practising as a doctor of medicine? A. Six months—I was admitted as a member of the College of Physicians last June—before that I was a member of the College of Surgeons, and of the Apothecaries' Company as well—I have been practising in London nine or ten years—the payment or non-payment of the 30l. would not have altered the evidence I have to give—Mr. Constable had made me a present of the picture about eighteen months before his death—I had failed to re
move it from his house during the time he was at Lewisham—Mr. Stanley had often promised to bring it to town, but he never did—after his death I applied to the prisoner, as Stanley's representative—about two months ago Miss Constable sent it to a place for me, from which I removed it

WILLIAM LISTER . I am a cloth-factor, and live in Basinghall-street, City. I am a member of the Common Council—I was an old acquaintance of the late Mr. Richard Constable—I know his handwriting—do not be
lieve the signature to this deed to be his handwriting.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you ever see Mr. Constable write on parchment? A. I do not know that I have—I am confident this is not his—I have letters in my pocket which I received from him—I have been looking at those letters—I do not see anything tremulous in this sig
nature—I do not think it is at all like his—it is totally unlike it—it does not bear the least resemblance, in any one of the letters—I do not think it would deceive me for an instant—I have a letter of his in my pocket, dated as late as May, 1840, and one of Nov. 1839—he was in the habit of corre
sponding with me up to as late as May, 1840, on matters of business, rela
tive to his estate—the signature to this letter (marked E) is more like his

writing, but I have my doubts of it, I do not think it is his—that I think is his (marked D) and this (marked A); I have doubts upon this (marked C)—I do not recollect ever seeing any such a flourish to the "C"—the finish to the "e" resembles his more—I have not been in the habit of seeing him sign his name "Richard," only "R"—this is "Richard" at length, and I do not recollect ever seeing his "C" with such a flourish underneath—I cannot say that this is his signature (H)—the "e" does not finish in his usual way, and the top part of the "C" is different to what he used to make—I doubt that being his—I know Miss Constable—I have seen her at her father's, when I have called to see him—she used to pass by the name of Watts—the last time I called to see them was the 10th of Feb., 1840—I have not seen him or her since—they were then at Lewisham—I do not know her handwriting—I never saw her write, nor ever received letters from her—I do not consider the signature to this (G) to be Mr. Constable's—I knew Stanley in the wool-trade—I met him at Mr. Constable's latterly.

----THOMPSON, M. D. I am a nephew of the late Mr. Richard Constable. I knew his handwriting very well—I certainly think the signa
ture, "Richard Constable," to this deed, is not his writing—there is less of flourish in it than he always used—it is certainly an imitation of his writing, but it is clearly not his—I have not a doubt about it.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You have seen that before, have you not? A. I saw it here on Friday—I looked at it for some seconds or minutes, as I have looked at it now—I do not think I ever saw my uncle sign a deed—it does bear some resemblance to his writing—I never should have suspected it to have been his, if I had seen it—I should certainly say it if clearly not his—when it was put into my hand I had been informed that the question was, whether it was a forgery or no forgery—it bears some resemblance to his writing; not a strong resemblance; I think it is an imitation—I can swear I think it is not my uncle's writing—this paper marked (C) is a good deal more like his writing—I should believe it was his, except that it is "Richard" at length, and forty-nine times out of fifty it was "R" only—I think it is his, with that exception—I cannot certainly say whether I ever saw him sign "Richard"—it bears a very close resemblance to his writing—this paper marked (A) I should take as his writing—I have no doubt about it—the word "Constable" is very like his, I think it is his writing.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you live at No. 129, Piccadilly? A. Yes—my uncle resided at Lewisbam formerly, and latterly at Kensington—he was the brother of the late Mr. Abraham Constable, who lived at Lewisham many years, and was a magistrate there—this property originally belonged to him—he built the house.

FREDERICK JOSEPH WRIGHT . I am keeper of the Records of the Court of Chancery—I produce the original answer of Frederick Charles Burnham Blackwell and Phœbe Blackwell to a bill—here is the answer, and here the bill—there was also an answer of Miss Constable, that is not here—it could have been if it was wanted.

THOMAS HILL
re-examined. I believe the signature to this answer to be the prisoner's handwriting. (The following extract was here read front the an
swer:)—"But they do allege, as the fact is, that the said Richard Constable did in his life-time execute an indenture, bearing date 30th Dec., 1840, under which the said Joseph Stanley claimed to be entitled to the equity of redemp
tion in the said mortgage.

JOB JONES . I am a linen-draper, and live at Islington. The prisoner was apprenticed to me—he served about four years and a quarter—I know his handwriting—I saw very little of it while he was with me, not sufficient to

swear to it—the attestation to this deed seems very much like hit writing—I cannot swear to it—it is something similar—I should believe and rather think it was his:—(The following extract from the Bill in Chancery, was here read:—"And whether they do not allege, and insist that the said Richard Constable in his lifetime, and Elizabeth Hollis Constable since, have or not executed the said deed to Joseph Stanley deceased, and other documents Under which be became or claimed to be entitled to some estate and interest in the said mortgage.")

CHARLOTTE STANLEY . I am the wife of John Stanley, a surgeon, and live in Commercial-road, Lambeth—he is the son of the late Joseph Stanley—I was acquainted with Joseph Stanley—he was the prisoner's uncle—I knew him in the years 1836, 1837, and 1838—he was very badly off at that time—I frequently lent him money—he was in a state of poverty during the years 1835, 1836, 1837, and 1838—I know that by his coming to me, and borrowing 1s. and 6d.—he wan in the habit of doing to—I know the pri
soner—I never saw him and Stanley together in the Fleet—I have been frequently in the Fleet, but I never saw Stanley there—he went to the coffee-room—I never saw him and the prisoner together—I do not know whether the prisoner was in the habit of associating with Stanley—I saw the prisoner's sister, Phœbe, at the time her father lay dead—I am not aware that the prisoner was in the habit of associating with Phœbe.

DR. LEVER re-examined. I did not see Stanley at any time on the 31st of Dec., until he called at my house—I did not see him at Mr. Con
stable's house on the 30th—I never saw the prisoner at Mr. Constable's.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. About how long altogether, putting both your visits together, do you think you were in the house that day? A. Half or three quarters of an hour, including both visits—his daughter nursed him.

CHARLOTTE STANLEY
re-examined. I belive the prisoner was aware that Joseph Stanley was in great poverty, from different conversations that I have heard when I have been with some part of the family—I never learnt it from the prisoner himself—I was very little with him—I have seen very little of him—I have heard that Stanley was in the habit of going to the Fleet Prison, but I did not see him—William Blackwell, the prisoner's brother, was in the Fleet—I do not know from the prisoner, or from anybody in his presence, whether he knew of Stanley's going there—I have heard him speak ill of Stanley.

MARY WAGNOR . I did live at No. 19, Liverpool-street, Camden-town, but now live at No. 16, Stanmore-street, St. Paneras-road. I knew Joseph Stanley—he was in poverty—he came to me the year the Queen was crowned, in the summer time, and was there about seven or eight months—I cannot say exactly to a month, but he left me about Easter, and I was very glad to get rid of him—I never saw the prisoner.

ELIZABETH JENKINSON . I live at No. 15, Swinton-street, Gray's-inn-road. The late Joseph Stanley lodged at my father's house for about ten weeks, in the year 1838—during that time his circumstances were very poor indeed—his wife and three children lived with him—they appeared very pool in their circumstances, and their clothing was poor—the children were con
stantly coming into our kitchen complaining of hunger, and their clothing exhibited poverty in the extreme—this was about the middle of April, 1838—he was to pay 12s. a week for his lodging, which he did for the first three weeks, and afterwards we had it by instalments—I know nothing of the pri
soner—I never saw him before—I remember Stanley's wife being confined—she had no doctor until afterwards, and no nurse was spoken to—she had her sister to nurse her afterwards—there were very few clothes for the child.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Is 1838 the last time you speak of Stanley, within your knowledge? A. It is—he did not go about with ragged clothes like a beggar, but his children and his wife did—he generally went out decently dressed, like a respectable person.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you any idea how he got his living at that time? A. He told us he was a wool-stapler.

----YACKNEY. I am an engineering surveyor, and live in London-road, Southwark. I knew the late Joseph Stanley from eighteen to twenty years—in 1836, I dined with him at one of his son's, Mr. John Stanley, in Her
cules-buildings, Lambeth—I knew him, and saw him in the years 1835, 1836, 1837, and 1838—I think I saw him up to about the latter part of Sept, 1838—he did not appear to be a person of property, on the contrary—the first time I met with him he appeared very needy, and said he was travel
ling, selling cigars and tea by commission—I should say his circumstances were very indifferent—there was every appearance of poverty.
Q. Did you ever know him to be in a condition to lend 800l. or 1000l. A. I should rather question such a thing, certainly—I should say certainly not.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What period of 1838 do you speak of? A. That was the last time I saw him—it was in the City, at the latter part of Sept., I should say about the 20th—I never had any dealings or transactions with him, beyond sometimes giving him a glass of stout, and a sandwich—that was the last refreshment we had together—I never let him go by without speaking, because I was always soliciting him to do something for his son—he was engaged in Chancery matters at that time.

EDMUND MESSENGER . I am a tailor, and live at Camberwell. I know the prisoner, and have often seen him write—the signature, "F. C. B. Black
well," attesting this deed, I believe to be the prisoner's handwriting; also the writing above, "By the within named Richard Constable and Elizabeth Hollis Constable, in the presence of"—that is all in his handwriting.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you known him? A. From the year 1839—I did not live with him then—he was intro
duced to me by a person named Smith—I was arrested for debt in 1840—the prisoner did not become bail for me on that occasion—I drew a bill on him about that time, for money which he owed me for clothes, and it was never paid—I went to live with him at Croydon, and assisted him in his shop there—that was two years after I drew the bill on him—he has never paid me the money, I could not receive it, for when I failed I made an assignment of my property—he did not make any charge against me after I had been with him about three months—he did not give me into custody—he did not charge me with robbing him of 4l. 16s., nor did he give me into custody in the presence of one Thomas Clack—that I swear—he never threatened to give me into custody—he said there was a balance of 4l. 16s. or 4l. 18s. due, and we proved afterwards that there was no deficiency whatever—he did not, to my knowledge, say that I had appropriated it to my own use—he did not threaten to give me into custody on account of that deficiency, or any thing to that effect, to my knowledge—this is the very first I ever heard of it—he did not charge me with embezzlement—I did not leave immediately after that—I remained two or three months after he mentioned about the 4l. 16s.—I assisted him when I was in business—I have often seen him write.

ARTHUR WIGTON GRANT . I am a cowkeeper, and have lived at Lewis
ham all my life. I knew Joseph Stanley, and know the prisoner—after Mr. Constable left Mount Pleasant-house, the prisoner came to live there with two females—I cannot say in what year that was—it is about two years ago, or rather better, perhaps—I do not know that I ever saw Stanley there with

them—I remember the time when the furniture was taken away from Mount Pleasant—I did not see Stanley with the prisoner on that occasion—a carrier of the name of Lane removed part of the furniture, in the prisoner's pre
sence—that was on the 4th of June, 1841—I purchased some little articles of the prisoner from the yard, and paid him for them—that was on the 4th of June—I have seen him write—I believe the signature to this deed to be his writing—I cannot speak to the words, "By the within-named," &c.—(looking at a paper)—I got this piece of paper from the prisoner on the 4th of June, the day it is dated—I agreed with the prisoner to purchase a field of grass—that was one of Mr. Constable's grass-fields—on my agreeing to purchase it, he wrote that paper—I paid him 5l. on the day it was purchased, and was to pay 5l. more on the 26th of December following—I did not pay that according to agreement—I imagined that he had a proper right to the grass, or else I should not have purchased it—I cut the grass, and made it on the premises, and stacked it on my own—I cannot say that I ever saw the prisoner and Stanley together—I have very often seen Stanley at Mount Pleasant, not during the time the prisoner was living there, but previously—I believe Stanley lived, at Mount Pleasant—he very often used to go up and down the lane.

ELIZABETH HOLLIS CONSTABLE . I am the daughter of the late Richard Constable. I resided with him down to the time of his death—he died on the 31st of Dec., 1840, in West-square, Lambeth—he was quite unconscious on the day he died, and also the day before—I knew Joseph Stanley—he came to my father's house, in West-square, the day my father died—I am not quite certain that he was not there the day before—I cannot recollect, but I do not think he was—previous to that I had not seen him for a very considerable time, perhaps three weeks—it was about half-past six o'clock in, the evening when he came on the 31st—he saw my father—I requested him to go for Dr. Lever, and he went—he was a very short time in the house before he went for the doctor—a few minutes, perhaps—he was in my sight all the time—when he came back my father had expired—I can scarcely swear that he was there on the 30th, but I think he was.

Q. Are you able to say whether any business was transacted, any signing of deeds, or anything of that sort, either on the 30th or 31st, by your father? A. Decidedly not—the signature to this deed is not my father's, nor is this mine—this letter (marked A) is not my father's writing—nor is this one, (marked B) mine—my father generally signed his name "Richard" in full—the signature to this (A) is "Rich" abbreviated—it is a good imitation of my father's writing, but it is not his—I first saw the prisoner at Mr. Birch's office, I should say at the latter end of June, 1841—that was before I went to Ireland—I afterwards accepted a situation in a nobleman's family in Ireland, and was absent from England for some time—I came over to England on hearing of Stanley's death, and had some interviews with the prisoner, not many—I claimed some furniture in the house at Lewisham, and general property—in pursuance of that, I went to the prisoner's house in Crawford-street—I returned to Ireland, I believe, from my visit to England; and returned again for good on the 18th of Nov., 1841—I went to Crawford-street about a week before Christmas, 1841—the prisoner was carrying on business there at that time—I remember an occasion when there was a conversation respect
ing this deed—the prisoner's mother and wife were present then—the conver
sation began with an inquiry respecting the furniture, and they were indignant and rude about it—his wife said that they had a right to the furniture, for that my father owed them 800l.—the prisoner was not present at that time—he came in afterwards—he was in and out of the room—he might have heard the

conversation—I do not know whether he did or not—he and his wife left the house with me; and as we were going along Crawford-street, I said it was quite time that we had a perfect understanding respecting the furniture and property that had been removed from Lewisham—they said they considered the furni
ture theirs, for that my father owed Mr. Stanley 800l., and Mr. Stanley had left everything to them—I said it was untrue, he never owed him anything—Mrs. Blackwell said he did, for they had a deed for it—I said, "You have no such thing, no such deed"—the prisoner said they had, for he and his wife had witnessed it—I replied, if they had, it was a forgery, for they never saw my father—the prisoner seemed very much alarmed on that, turned himself round, and said, "You don't mean to say that you charge us with forgery?"—I said, "If there is such a thing existing, it is a forgery"—Mrs. Blackwell said, "No, it will be no forgery, unless we swear to it"—I said I felt myself very ill treated, and I should not let it rest where it was—the prisoner said he was going to Chatham, where he had a house of business, and should return in three days—in the course of conversation about witnessing the deed, he said that his uncle had filled in the vacant names, and they had witnessed it at his (the prisoner's) house, at Camberwell—the prisoner kept a draper's shop at Camberwell—my father was never there.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. When were you lucky enough to have this conversation? A. About a week before Christmas, 1841, in Craw
ford-street—I rather think there were lodgers in the house there—I mentioned this conversation to Mr. Petch, and I mentioned it to Mr. Boys, the following year, in 1842—I mentioned it immediately to my friends, of whom Mr. Petch was one—he is a housekeeper, in St. John-street—I had the prisoner taken up a very short time ago—I never saw him after this conversation, to have an opportunity of doing so before—I was not indicted by him before I charged him—either be or his wife appeared against me at Union Hall—I appeared at Union Hall on a charge of having committed a forcible entry—that was at the instance of the prisoner's sister—she appeared there—it was after that that I had the prisoner taken up—I was not taken into custody—I had gone to a house in which the prisoner's sister lived—I went with Mr. Fluker, the attorney's clerk, not with other persons—the house was not broken into in my presence—I found the door broken.

Q. Did you not go in the dusk of the evening, and after you had sent per
sons forward, find the door broken open? A. I sent no person forward—I was invited by Miss Ann Blackwell to take away all the furniture I found there—she brought me the keys to unlock all the doors—I do not know whether that was after the onter door was broken open—I did not know whether there was any door broken open—the door was open—I do not say it was broken open—I found it open—I found Miss Ann Blackwell there, and Phœbe Blackwell, and her nieces—I saw no one else—I saw Mr. Fluker—there were a great number of persons—there was no riot—we had applied to Mr. Cottingham for a warrant, and he considered it was the subject of an action—we were not three minutes about the premises before I found the door open—I will swear my friends were not wailing there the whole afternoon to get in—Mr. Fluker was not, to my knowledge.

Q. How came you to go there that evening? A. I had been there for some days before—the property was mine, and they were conveying it stealth
ily away—I had been watching for some days before—I had not been watching that afternoon—I was visiting at a house opposite, at Mr. Clifford's, the assistant overseer—Rutland, the officer, was in the house with me—I did not know who he was then, but I afterwards knew he was an officer—I had taken tea at Mr. Clifford's—I hud been there in the course of the afternoon,

and walking to and fro in the street—I had been there some time watching my property—I was there perhaps six or seven hours, or more, to see that no
thing was taken away—Mr. Clifford advised me to remain there, and if I saw any one taking property away to detain it—it was in consequence of what he said that I walked to and fro to see what was going on—I went out, bearing cries of "Murder"—I had been sitting quietly in the parlour—the cries of "Murder" came from Sarah Blackwell, Miss Blackwell's niece—she said it was her—when I went over I found a number of persons in the house—Phœbe Black well was sent to prison—I have been indicted for a forcible entry—I went to Union-hall, and I dare say I was held to bail—(looking at the deed)—I think this signature, "Richard Constable," is not at all like my father's, not the least—it does not bear the least resemblance—I saw it at Union-hall—I had not my glasses on then—two deeds were put into my hand at the same moment, and I could not tell one from the other—I put on my glasses at Union-hall, but I had a very transient glance of the deed there—I have since seen it, and I then said I could not tell one from the other.

Q. When have you since seen it? A. At Union-hall—I do not know who showed it to me—I saw it at Union-hall before the Magistrate—I can
not recollect who showed it to me—the room was full of gentlemen—some
body showed it to me.

Q. Then first of all you doubted, then you put on your spectacles, and still doubted, and you have since seen it, and you do not doubt? A. Yes—it is not at all like my father's signature, nor is this signature at all like mine—it is of course an attempt, but it is not mine—they are both attempts—I am con
vinced it is an attempt, because it is a forged deed—it may bear a resemblance to my signature, but it is not mine—I have seen the deed, and examined it—(looking at a deed of confirmation)—this is my signature—I have seen this before—I executed this at Mr. Boys', in Ely-place—I signed it—I said at Union-hall that I did not recollect signing it—I could not till one from the other—I have always recollected signing a deed at Mr. Boys' office—I was always perfectly conscious that I bad done so—I signed it on the 14th of Dec., 1841—the prisoner had taken me to Mr. Boys', but he had not at that time a retainer from me as my solicitor—in the March following he wrote me a letter, to require that I would give him a few lines, appointing him my solicitor, a written retainer—at the time this deed was executed, the prisoner, Mr. Boys, (Mr. Martin, his clerk, I think,) and Mr. Austin, his partner, were present—Mr. Austin was, I am sure, and I think Mr. Martin was—I went to their office for the purpose of executing that deed—I cannot say that I knew the nature of the deed before I was called upon to execute it—I did not execute it without some hesitation—I asked Mr. Boys to explain it to me—it was not read to me, and he said it was necessary that it should be read, and he read a part of it, which included the name of Phœbe Blackwell—I remarked to him that I had never beard of Phœbe Blackwell before, and it was a very extraordi
nary thing to give a benefit to a person I had never seen or heard of—he said she was Mr. Blackwell's sister, and was so mixed up with her uncle's affairs, that it would make great confusion to separate them—(this was before I was charged with violently breaking into the house and taking the furniture)—I inquired of Mr. Boys if he knew this person, I having never seen her—he said he did not know much of her, or he did not know her; that he under
stood she was a lame person, and resided in Derbyshire—I had asked to have the contents of the deed explained, and they were explained so far—I did not know what I was signing.
Q. How came you, a person of your mature age, and apparent care and caution, to sign a deed when you did not know what it contained? A. The

prisoner came to me, on my return from Ireland, about the 19th of Nov., 1841, and after speaking of his uncle's death, he inquired what I was going to do respecting the freehold at Lewisham—I said, "I really hardly know what to do with it"—he said, did I know any gentleman who would relieve the free-hold from its difficulties; there was a mortgage of 2000l. due on it, and the interest—I said no, I did not know any gentleman that was so inclined—he then inquired if he paid off the mortgage, would I give him an interest in it?—I said it was a very pretty place, and I would give any gentleman an inter
est in it, who had the means of enjoying it—he inquired what I could live upon as an income—I said my views were humble, and a small income would support me—he said, could I live on 30l. a-year?—I said "Yes, I could"—he said if he were disposed to relieve it from its difficulties, would I give him an interest in it?—he said that he could do so—I inquired what his means were—he said he had 800l. his own property; that he had four shops of business, the one he resided in, one at Croydon, one in Crawford-street, and one at Chatham, and that in the course of a few months he should have a very respectable wholesale warehouse in Wood-street; that his brother would lend him 1000l., and that he had so much interest in the City, that he could pro
cure 3000l. or 4000l. at two hours' notice at any time—I said if he could do that, I could certainly see no objection to give him an interest in it—(at this time I had not seen the deed in question)—he inquired what the incumbrances were—I told him there was the bill of costs due to Mr. Parker; there was 2000l. owing to the mortgagee, with the interest accruing thereon; there were thir
teen guineas owing to the Bridge-house estate, for ground-rent for a field; that the house I had insured as long as I could for 1500l., but it was now falling in—he said that all those things he would immediately set smooth, that it was a very pretty place, and that in a fortnight or three weeks' time I should see it in as good condition as I had ever seen it before—(there are twelve acres of land to it)—I lent him a pencil, and he calculated what the sums would amount to, and said it would be no inconvenience to him, he could get it done very easily, and left me—I forgot to say that he likewise mentioned that Ely-place, Holbora, belonged to his family, and that they had a very great interest in one side of Earl-street, Blackfriars, if it did not wholly belong to them—no one was present at this conversation—(it occurred in the house of Mrs. Gibbs, No. 4, Kent-place, Pimlico, opposite the end of Lower Belgrave-street—Mrs. Gibbs is a very old friend of mine, and was thirteen years house-keeper to the late Sir William Stirling—on my return from Ireland I wrote to the prisoner, and he wrote to say he would call on me, which he did)—when he had calculated what the amount would be, he said he would see Mr. Boys, of Ely-place, on the subject—I attended at Mr. Boys's, I believe, a day or two afterwards, but the next evening I went to the prisoner in Southampton-street, as I wanted to talk to him about the furniture—he had come so late, that the evening was too far gone to enter on the subject, and I went to him next evening to talk about the furniture, and general property—there were papers of great value to me—when I got there he was not at home—a Mr. Newhall came in soon after I arrived, and after waiting some time, and com
plaining that the prisoner never kept his appointments, he left the bouse for a very short time—the prisoner returned home in the meantime, but I did not talk about the papers and other matters of consequence—Mr. Newhall came in again, and complained that Mr. Birch had behaved excessively ill, and said that he was no lawyer, and did not know what he was about—that seemed to be conversation between themselves—they seemed to have been to Mr. Birch on some occasion, and were dissatisfied with him—he said Mr. Birch was a fool; that he had prepared a deed of reversion for the Thompson family

to sign, which is a numerous branch; that he had shown no consideration, and therefore the deed was invalid, and was of no use—I did not say one word to the prisoner about the furniture, or other matters upon which I went to see him—I was there perhaps an hour, or more—I went late, because I would not interrupt his business, his evenings I considered more at leisure—I waited for some time—Mr. Newhall said that Mr. Birch had erred in his judgment; that he understood what my very liberal proposal had been to Mr. Blackwell, and in the formation of another deed, great care must be taken not to com
mit such an error—I left the house without mentioning the subject on which I went—Mr. Newhall broke in quite on another subject, said Mr. Stanley had robbed him, and that he had been often deceived by him, and I had no oppor
tunity of saying any thing about the furniture—he said Mr. Stanley had made false representations to him, and if the prisoner did not turn out an honest man he should suffer very considerably, for he had put 800l. worth of goods into bis hands—I do not think I went to Mr. Boys the next day—I went there a few days after the prisoner's visit to me at Pimlico—I did not mention any thing about the furniture and other important matters at Mr. Boys's—I did not doubt the prisoner's honesty at the moment, until I had fully executed the deed, and then they shuffled altogether about the furniture, and would not give any part of it up—previous to going to Mr. Boys, the prisoner had given me his promise that the furniture, and other things that belonged to me should be given up; that it was in the possession of his mother, who lived in Camberwell, but was at that time in Derbyshire, and he apologised for not being able to go with me at that time—that was between the 6th of Sept., when I arrived in London, and that day month, when I was in Ireland again—the prisoner wrote to me in Ireland, and his address was Southampton-street—I was very anxious to know what he had done with the property generally, and when I came to England I took a cab from the Euston station, and went through London to Southampton-street, though I was very much fatigued—I saw the prisoner standing in his shop—I did not know till then that he was a draper—the moment he recognised me, having seen me at Mr. Birch's, he apologised for not being able to ask me into his sitting-room, as there were some gentlemen there on particular business—I inquired after his uncle, whose death had taken place in the interval, and which was the cause of my coming to London—he said he had died in his house; that he had had every care taken of him; that he was a very distressed man, that if he had not done so, he must either have died in the street, or have been taken to the workhouse—this conversation was in the prisoner's shop, in Southampton-street—I do not know whether we were quite alone—there might have been some of his men in the shop—I dare say there were—two women passed while I sat there, who I have since discovered to be his wife, and Phoebe Blackwell—they were not there—they passed through into the inner room, and shut the door after them.

Q. Now when you were at Mr. Boys' office, do you mean to say thai this deed, to which you then affixed your signature, was not distinctly explained to you in all its parts? A. It was not—I do not know the points of it at all—I know nothing that it contains more than this, that Phoebe Blackwell's name was contained in it, and I objected to her name, not knowing her—I afterwards agreed that her name should remain, as I had a great deal of confi
dence in the prisoner, and Mr. Boys said, "It will make a great deal of con
fusion if we strike her out, and it will not affect your interests at all"—I said, "I know nothing of this man except being Mr. Stanley's nephew, and he has the appearance of an honest man," but I said, "Does it not seem very odd, Mr. Boys, to give an interest to a person I never saw?"
Q. Is that all you knew with respect to the deed, that it gives an interest

in something to Miss Phoebe Blackwell? A. The prisoner in the mean time had brought the draft to me, two or three evenings after I had been to Mr. Boys—it was all done within a few days—the prisoner called on me twice at Pimlico—he brought me the draft, and said he had brought it for my perusal—I said, "Mr. Blackwell, I cannot understand it, it is a great roll of paper, I shall not understand one-half of it, and if you comply with your promises to me, that is all I require," and he took it away with him again—it was soon after I arrived in England that he brought the draft to me, and soon after his first visit to me at Pimlico—no one was present when he brought the draft to me—he begged that no one might be present.

Q. When did he beg that? A. On the evening that he first proposed it—I proposed that I should name his offer to some of ray friends—he said, "No, don't do that, you will be vacillating about it, you won't find any one else that will make you a better offer, and don't mention it to any one"—I did not open or look at the draft at all—I did not make inquiries respecting the furniture when he brought the draft—I paid a great many visits to South
ampton-street after that—it was before he brought the draft that I went there and saw Mr. Newhall there—that was between his first and second visit to me at Pimlico—I did not ask him about the furniture when be brought the draft, because he came so late in the evening and hurried away again—I do not know how long he was there—he scarcely sat down—when I saw the roll of paper I said, "This is all leather and prunella to me, I shall not understand it; and if you make good your promises to me that is all I shall require"—I had told Mr. Boys the same.
Q. When you went respecting the deed, you said be need not explain it, it was all leather and prunella to you? A. Yes.

Q. Then you signed it, making that observation, did you? A. It was not ready to sign at that time—Mr. Boys appointed me to go there one day, and there was a mistake in the stamp, and then he appointed for me to come on the next evening—I went next evening—the prisoner came and fetched me from Pimlico in a cab, and I then signed the deed—that was on the 14th of Dec.—it was then that the observation was made about Phoebe Blackwell's name being in it.

Q. Was any portion of it read then? A. I said that I thought it was of no use to read it, I did not care about it; if Mr. Blackwell fulfilled his en
gagements, as I had no doubt he would, I did not want to hear any thing about it—Mr. Boys said he never allowed any lady or gentleman to sign any thing in his office without reading it, and in that case he read a part of it—I believe that was what Mr. Boys said—he read the part attaching to Phoebe Blackwell and her brother—I said to Mr. Boys, "Stop, sir, if you please, I don't want such a name as Phoebe Blackwell, I know nothing about her," and he then made the remark about her being so mixed up with her uncle's affairs.
COURT. Q. Was any copy of this deed delivered to you? A. No.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What did the deed say with respect to the prisoner and Phoebe Blackwell? I cannot recollect what it was he read—I recollect Phoebe Blackwell's name was introduced, and I objected to it—it was a small portion of it that was read—after reading it he said, "Are you satisfied?"—I said, "I do not know that I have any reason to be dissatisfied; I dare say I shall find this young man very honourable, and that is all I shall require"—Mr. Boys said, "It won't affect your interests at all" and he then invited me round to his desk to sign it—I was going to sign it, he called Mr. Martin, his clerk, I think, and he said, "Stop, Miss Constable, before you sign it I
will call my partner, Mr. Austen, in to witness it"—he did so, and it was signed.

Q. Did you believe that it would not affect your interests at all when you signed it? A. Except, so far that it would relieve me from all the difficulties I was labouring under—I was frightened to move—I considered, by affixing my signature, that I was conveying the freehold estate to the prisoner for a consideration, for my living—I was under an impression that it would be a great benefit to me—the prisoner had firmly impressed on my mind that it would not affect my interests, and not to mention it to Mr. Boys—if the pri
soner had performed his promise honestly he would have had a great deal to pay—he is a very young man.

Q. You have spoken in high terms of Stanley; at that time had you any reason to alter your opinion of Stanley's honour? A. The first doubt I had thrown up on Stanley's honour was by Mr. Newhall, who very much astonished me in depreciating him in every way—up to that time I had not the least doubt of Stanley—I had a very high opinion of him, and so had my father—he died with that impression—Stanley had been very much trusted by my father and myself, we placed the greatest confidence in him—he was con
stantly with us during the time we resided at Lewisham—it was a lone place, he resided in the house—my father was eighty-seven years of age—we had known Stanley ever since the year 1810—he was then a rich merchant, in King's Arms-yard, Coleman-street, in the wool trade—when he afterwards came to us, he represented that he had been some years in America—he was trusted and confided in by my father and myself from the moment of his putting his foot into our house, from the year 1837, and then he represented that he had just arrived in England—he resided in our house at Lewisham—we went from town to Lewisham—my father died in West-square—Stanley did not reside in that house—we had been there from the period of leaving our house in the June preceding—the house, Mount Pleasant, at Lewisham, was let furnished to a Mr. Freeman, a solicitor, of Coleman-street—I never saw Newhall till I saw him at the prisoner's house—I saw him after that—I have seen him about three times in the course of my life.

Q. Look at that paper, (marked X) whose handwriting is that? only look at the signature, if you please? A. I have seen what the subject-matter is; I think it is my signature—(looking at an account)—this is neither my writing or my signature—I see what it is, I have heard of it before—I have not seen what the contents are—Mr. Newhall told a gentleman in the gallery of this Court, the other day, that I had signed an agreement for 1,200l.—I have never seen this paper before.

Q. Then, how do you know that this has anything to do with Mr. New
hall? A. Why, there is his name attached to it—I do not know what it alludes to—Mr. Newhall said there was an acknowledgment for 1,200l.

Q. Did you ever see Mr. Newhall on the subject of any sum of money owing to Mr. Stanley? A. I never saw Newhall bnt once at the prisoner's—I have seen him in his own counting-house, in the presence of Mr. Petch—whatever transaction took place with the prisoner relating to Mount Pleasant was in his own house—there was a transaction with Mr. Newhall and the pri
soner relating to Mount Pleasant—no mention was made of any claim of Stanley's of money due to him from my father or myself, or to the prisoner—an account was drawn out by Mr. Newhall regarding the deed Mr. Boys was going to prepare—he said, as Mr. Birch had fallen into so great an error in preparing a deed of reversion, it must be carefully guarded against, and he consulted with the prisoner what sum should be entered to make the next

deed I was about to execute legal—it was stated that there had been no con
sideration shown in the former deed.

Q. Was it stated also that the sums had not been filled up in the former deed? A. I know no deed but the one the Thompsons had executed—I know nothing about sums in a former deed—I never saw the Thompsons' deed of reversion, but they told me it was without consideration, therefore it was of no use—it was not stated that the sums had not been filled up in a former deed, I will swear that—the account was drawn out to insert a certain sum to make the deed that I was about to convey to the prisoner valid—the prisoner proposed that it should be 800l.—Newhall said no, he thought two sums of 400l. would be much better—I know of no account—there was no memorandum, or any paper written, in my presence.

Q. Did you not just now say there was an account? A. That is the ac
count that you have; that is the one I heard Mr. Newhall had spoken of the other day, when he said he had an account for 1,200l.—when I was at the prisoner's, the prisoner, Newhall, and myself were present, and alone—I saw Newhall writing, but not on such an account as that; it was a small piece of paper, which he took out of his pocket, the back of a letter, or something he was making memorandums, and certain sums were named—the prisoner said it should be 800l., that would be sufficient—they first talked of 1,000l.—Newhall thought it would be too much, and then the prisoner said it should be 800l.—Newhall said he thought two sums of 400l. each would do much better—that was to make the deed I was going to give to the prisoner valid—Newhall said that a deed without a consideration was of no use—what memo
randum there was he made himself with his pencil, and Mrs. Blackwell ob
jected to it—she put her head just inside the room; she was not in the room, but she called the prisoner out of the room—I heard her say something to him, and he said, "Oh, no, you may trust him with anything," and she went down stairs again—I did not write at all, I will swear that—the memorandum was made with a pencil, which Newball took out of bis own pocket.

Q. About how long were you arranging all this? A. The arrangement, whatever it was, was not more than an hour altogether; I dare say it was an hour—Mr. Newhall, in the prisoner's presence, went into the history of the prisoner's uncle, and the prisoner sat quite dumb—he came to me next evening, and I said I thought Mr. Newhall's conduct with respect to his uncle was very extraordinary indeed—he said he thought so too; he never was so astonished at anything in his life; and be then again repeated that his uncle had no funds, and he would have died in the workhouse if it had not been for him.

Q. Just look at this paper, you may read it carefully? A. There is not one word of truth in it—the sums of money that appear there as paid, were paid out of a sum of 300l., for which we had sold our house at Kennington, in which my father had resided for fifty-two years, and I can give you the number of every note that was paid—it was in 50l. notes.

COURT. Q. What is this paper then? A. It is a paper stating that Mr. Stanley has paid all these sums, every shilling of which was put into his pocket, and independent of that he makes a charge here for a sow and eight pigs, Which I paid myself to the man, and he never saw the man—it is entirely a fictitious account—we gave him 30l. for the carpets—"acceptances for 25l." we gave him—the stoves he bought of a Mr. Bell, in the new street that turns out by the Bank, I forget the name—he had 50l. for that—the house painting was 115l., of which we paid every shilling—we paid Collett 40l. ourselves—"balance of a bill of 6l. 15s. 9d.," we owed no such balance—"a bill of costs, 22l. 19s.," which we paid ourselves—he had the money—"Ssmith's bill,

for bell-hanging, 44l. "—that was a man in Lewisham—we paid him, and it was paid by a bill which was taken up at Davies', the wax-chand
ler's, in St. Martin's-lane—"paid on account of furniture, bought at the sale at Shooter's-hill, 17l. 12s. cow and calf, 18l. 15s.; ditto, ditto, 19l.; a red cow, 13l. 5s. "—they did not come to half the money—we have the account of them—they were bought of Mr. Longdon, of Shooter's-hill—it is true that Stanley accompanied us, but my father paid the money from his own pocket—from his own funds—here is "expenses to Wales, 50l.," there is not a word of truth in it at all—this paper is not Stanley's writing, nor is it mine.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Now Miss Constable, I ask you distinctly, whether you ever settled an account with Mr. Newhall? A. I did not—no ac
connt of any kind was ever prepared by him in my presence, more than some memorandum which he made, which I understood was two sums of 400l. each, and nothing more that I was aware of—I have no doubt this (the letter marked C) is my father's handwriting, and this also (D)—these letters have been picked out from hundreds of others, which have been stolen from our private papers, at the house at Lewisham—boxes, trunks, and drawers full—these letters are some of them.

COURT. Q. In saying, that the letter marked "D" is genuine, do you speak from the signature alone, or from the body of the letter? A. I have looked at them both, one is a letter written to Mr. Stanley in Wales.—(One letter was dated 1838, the other 1839.)

MR. BODKIN. Q. When your father and you first became acquainted with Stanley, he was a merchant of opulence in London? A. He was—in the year 1837, he occasionally called at our house at Kennington, but he did not become an inmate of our house till we went to Lewisham which was about June, 1838—he came to us with the intention of paying 2l. a week for his board—that was his own proposal—he was very delicate about it—he said he would not come on any other terms—he never paid a farthing from the time he came, till he quitted—he wanted assistance constantly—he seemed to be straitened in his circumstances at that time, but he showed us a document, which would entitle him in a short time to 80,000l.—it was a skin, which had much the apperance of one of these deeds—we never got any produce from that security.

Q. Were you aware of the existence of any such deed as this charged to be forged, when you had the conversation with the prisoner, in which he proposed that you should be allowed 30l. a year, and that that was to form the foundation of some other deed to be prepared and executed? A. Certainly not—the conversation at which Newhall was present, was at the time it was agreed that the consideration should be first 1,000l., then 800l., and then two sums of 400l. each, but I did not agree to any of them—it was their own sug
gestion—this account was not shown to me then—no paper was shown to me at all—there were no papers on either side—this is the first time I have ever seen such an account—I was certainly not aware of the existence of this forged deed when I executed this other deed—the prisoner made the items for the deed that I did execute—there were two small estates, one at Caermarthen and one at Huntingdon, and he remarked to me, "Here are two small pro
perties, what will you do with them?" "Why," I said, "they are totally unencumbered, Mr. Black well?"—he said, "Well, so they are, but would you have any objection to my including them, and then I can act as your agent? I will collect the rents for you, and you will never have any trouble," and they were included—the 30l. was to be founded on that part of the property which was under mortgage, independent of the Huntingdon and Caermarthen property—it was when I went to sign the deed, that I asked a

question about Phoebe Blackwell, and Mr. Boys told me she was a lame person residing in Derbyshire—I have since seen her, and she is not at all a person answering that description, she is a tall hale woman—the furniture at the house at Lewisham was worth about 600l., but then the wine and plate, and other property was locked up, and not included—the house had been let furnished, at five guineas a week—I do not know what has become of the plate—I have never seen any of the furniture, except what I have been indicted about, and which I got, but that is so dreadfully mutilated, and in such an imperfect state, that I sold it to a broker for 3l.—I was indicted for getting that by a forcible entry—there was no great quantity of plate left in the house—a little service, and nothing more—my father had a great objection to having much—it was worth, I should think, 30l.—we had eighteen dozen of foreign wine there, and forty gallons of home made wine—I have not got any of that back—I understand they were very highly dissipated, and drank very ex
travagantly—the prisoner promised that when I was settled, and was willing to receive the furniture, he would give it all up—that was shortly before I signed this deed—after I had signed the deed, I made a great many applica
tions for the furniture, but never got anything—this paper is my handwriting—it is the retainer, Which I gave Mr. Boys—it bears date 20th of Dec., 1841, but I did not sign it till March.
Q. Then in March you had a paper given yon, dated back to December, which you signed? A. Yes, I did not send the retainer by post; I took it to Mr. Boys.
MR. BIRCH re-examined. Q. Upon whose application did you part with the deed said to be forged? A. The application was in writing in the first instance—this is it—it is signed by the prisoner.

THOMAS HILL
re-examined. This signature, "F. C. B. Blackwell," is the prisoner's writing.

MR. BIRCH re-examined. This is dated, "Southampton-street, Camberwell, 27th of Oct. 1841," and is addressed "Messrs. Sutcliffe and Birch"—it is—(reads)—"Gentlemen, As devisees and executors of the will of the late Mr. Joseph Stanley, deceased, we request and hereby authorise you to deliver the papers and documents which have belonged to him and his estate, particularly the deeds relating to the Lewisham estate, to Messrs. Hale, Boys, and Austen, on their receipt; and we will thank you to furnish them or us with the particulars of the demand you have against the late Mr. Stanley's estate."—This is signed by the prisoner and Phoebe Blackwell—that ultimately led to giving up the forged deed; but something else passed between the letter and the giving up of the deed—on the receipt of this letter, I think, we sent the prisoner Stanley's bill, and then we gave up all the papers belonging to Stanley, but we did not give up the deed in question, as we had not re
ceived the bill against Mr. Constable—Hale, Boys, and Austen then took out a summons, which I hold in my hand—they were then acting for the prisoner—it is a summons before a judge, to show cause why we did not give up the deed—the judge discharged the summons with costs—he said we had a clear lien on the deed for the debt against Constable, on the assumption that Constable having ordered the deed to be prepared would have had to pay the expense of it—Hale, Boys, and Austen ultimately paid the amount, and the deed was given up—I think I was in the way when the forged deed was taken away—I was not in the room when it was given up—I was in my own room—I did not see the parties who came to claim it—I gave Coward, my clerk, instructions to give up the deed—I authorized him to part with it, in consequence of the communication which he made to me—I gave it him for that purpose—I knew from Coward that the prisoner

was then in the outer office—I had not actual knowledge of it—after Mr. Freeman quitted Mount Pleasant, the prisoner, his family, and Stanley, were in possession of it—I do not think Stanley died there—I went to see him there when he was very ill—the prisoner and hit family did not live there after Stanley's death.

(The instrument charged to be forged, was without stamp or date. It pur
ported to be an indenture of release and conveyance of certain hereditaments and premises from Richard Constable and Elizabeth Constable to Joseph Stan
ley, on trust, to pay to Aldridge, the mortgagee, 2000l.: also certain legal ex
penses to Messrs. Parker, and Messrs. Sutcliffe and Birch; and to the said Joseph Stanley, a debt of (leaving a blank for the amount) with interest there-on; the residue of the proceeds, if any, to be divided between the said Richard Constable and Elizabeth Hollis Constable.)

The Letters marked A, and B, put in by MR. CHAMBERS, were here read:—(A) "London, 3rd of Aug. 1840.—Gentlemen, I have looked over M Stanley's account, and find at different times money advanced by him to the amount of 822l. 12s., therefore it will be necessary that a trus
deed should, without delay, be drawn up to secure it, and also that my other creditors should be paid in full what is justly owing to them. I am, gen
tlemen, your obedient servant, RICHARD CONSTABLE. To Messrs. Sutcliffe and Birch."

(B) "London, 18th of Feb. 1841. Gentlemen, I hereby authorize and direct you to supply the blanks in the trust-deed executed by my late father, Richard Constable, Esq., on the 31st of Dec. last, by inserting the sum of 822l. 12s. as the debt owing to Mr. Stanley, and the sum of—, as being due to yourselves. I remain, gentlemen, yours obediently, ELIZABETH HOLLIS CONSTABLE. P.S. There are several sums due to Mr. Stanley on an account, 53l. 16s. 8d. paid to yourselves, and taxes due at Mount Pleasant for the same amount, 30l. on my own account, and also servant's wages from Oct. 1840 to the present time." Annexed to this was the fol
lowing:—"London, 24th of Dec. 1840.—Received of Mr. Stanley 51l. 16s. 8d., being a loan of 50l. lent on account of Mr. Constable on the 24th of Aug. 1839, and now repaid with interest from that period, for Messrs. Sutcliffe and Birch, 50l., interest 16s. 8d. 51l. 16s. 8d."

THOMAS NEWHALL . I live in Wood-street, Cheapside. In the year 1841, I had some transacttons with the prisoner, the result of which was that he was indebted to me about 1,258l. altogether—my trading account, I think was about 300l.—I took a shop in Southampton-street, Camberwell, for a nephew of mine—the prisoner afterwards had that shop from me and my partner—I believe part of the sum I have mentioned was the consideration for obtaining that shop, and there was one or two dishonoured bills—I knew a person named Stanley—I Cannot exactly remember to a month or so when the prisoner took possession of the Camberwell shop, but I think it was about Aug.—I think in 1841.

Q. Did you on any occasion go down and see Miss Constable there? A. I did—I went over to see Blackwell respecting my accounts—I think, as near as I can remember, that must have been some time about Dec., 1841, but I have not made myself acquainted with the dates—it was Dec. or Jan.—I will not be positive which—I was introduced to Miss Constable on that occa
sion—I was very anxious on account of my account being so very large, and I was introduced to Miss Constable respecting the amount of the property down at Lewisham—a conversation took place between myself, the prisoner,

and Miss Constable, on the subject of the property—it was stated either by Miss Constable or the prisoner, I cannot swear which, that the property at Lewisham had been disposed of to the amount of 4,500l., or guineas, to as
certain the real value, and that the prisoner was in a position to pay my account—whichever stated that, the other heard it—I believe, as far as I can possibly state, Miss Constable was appealed to by the prisoner—Miss Constable stated to me that there was a certain deed conveying the property from Mr. Constable to Stanley; that she was perfectly aware that Mr. Stanley or her
self, I will not be positive which, had given instructions to Mr. Birch to fill up a deed—I had been endeavouring to ascertain the value of the property, that I might take security from the prisoner.

Q. Did she say who were the parties to that deed? A. As far as my me
mory serves me, I understood that she had witnessed a deed conveying this property, which ought to be filled up—that she was a party to the deed—I will not say a witness—that she had witnessed, or was a party to a deed which required to be filled up, I believe, for the amount of 800l. and upwards (I had not at that time put an execution into the prisoner's house)—the prisoner or Miss Constable, when both were present, in the room, informed me that such a deed was in the hands of Mr. Birch, and I believe the prisoner said he had not the means to settle Mr. Birch's account—I went to the prisoner's house again, and saw Miss Constable, I believe about a week or ten days after; during that time I had advanced the prisoner the money to take the deeds out of Mr. Birch's hands—on the second occasion that I saw Miss Constable, I made a memorandum—this is it—(looking at the account produced)—it is my writing; I copied that from receipts which were placed before me, which I was informed Miss Constable was in possession of—Miss Constable and the prisoner together, informed me so—I believe the prisoner produced the receipts—he laid them before me, that they were from Miss Constable—that was not in Miss Con
stable's presence—I copied them in another room—they were both present after I copied them, when I laid the copy of the receipts before them—I can
not say in whose handwriting the part beginning, "I have carefully compared," is—I saw Miss Constable write the words "Elizabeth Hollis Constable" to this account—that was done after I had copied this from the receipts, and after she bad seen it—I believe she stated that the deed I have referred to was as a security for sums of money which Mr. Stanley had paid on behalf of her father, and that the receipts were for those sums—I left this account at South
ampton-street on that occasion—I do not recollect having it in my possession after that evening—I have never seen it since, to the best of my recollection, till this day.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you got the particulars of the prisoner's account with you? A. I have not, but I think my memory will serve me—I was security to Messrs. Costers, of Aldermanbury, to the amount of 300l. or 400l., for goods had by the prisoner—I did not put my name to a bill—I guaranteed the account, by giving a writing for any goods they might advance to the prisoner, to the amount of about 300l. odd—I was only guarantee, I believe, for 300l.—I was not guarantee for more than 300l., further than I believe, my word of honour—I am not certain whether I was guarantee for exactly 300l.—their account was 400l. which I paid them off in cash—I paid them in the year 1841, I believe—I cannot speak posi
tively to the date—I paid part, I believe, in 1841, and part in 1842—I can
not say how much I paid in 1841, unless I had my ledger here—I have not looked for the purpose of giving my evidence—I paid Costers in the whole, I believe, 490l.—I considered I was bound in honour to pay that amount—I paid it by two or three acceptances—I have not got the bills with me—they

can be produced—I paid them through the hands of Sir John Lubbock—I was also security to Walters, of Wood-street, for 118l. odd for goods the prisoner had in his trade, and Coster's was for goods had in his trade—I have not got an invoice of either of them—I cannot say that I never saw the in
voice—I might have seen it at the prisoner's—I cannot swear whether I have or not—I also became guarantee to Sargentson, Weston, and Co., Scotch warehousemen, about the same period—it was in 1841, and I think about March—I cannot swear to dates, unless I saw my ledger, and saw the time—I paid them 94l.—I was guarantee for about 100l.—I believe it was in 1841 that I became guarantee to them—I am not positive, without re
ferring to my books—the next sum I paid was 160l. to Mr. Birch, if my re
collection serves me, I advanced that on the prisoner's account, to get a deed out—I never got possession of that deed till it was handed to me by my solicitor, after a confirmation deed had been granted—I received it from my solicitor, I think about Jan. or Feb., 1842—Mr. Reynold's, of No. 10, Adelphi-street, Strand, is my solicitor.

Q. Pray have you ever been in any difficulties? A.
